Posts.Content: The recommendation to call your dr and ask exactly what they will do is excellent.  It is also a good chance to voice your concerns about being jumpy - your dr can make a note that an IV sedative might be desirable.  Here is a good article on wire localization and biopsy - I cannot say that your procedure will be exactly as this article says, but it is good basic information http://www.health.harvard.edu/diagnostic-tests/wire-localiza They will at least use a local anesthetic for the wire placement. It's possible they may start an IV first and give you a sedative before the entire procedure, but if they need you to be pretty mobile for the wire placement, my guess is that you won't get any heavy duty IV drugs until that is done. Also, on the day of your surgery, an anesthesiologist should come to talk with you before the procedure is done - make sure to mention then that you are nervous - ask them to do what they can to minimize your anxiety. I hope everything goes well for you, and that your biopsies are benign.  Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: Hi BettyBoob, Sounds like right now you have 2 primary concerns, and have not received reassurance nor adequate treatment for either one:  1.  you have breast pain for which you still aren't being treated  2. you are concerned this could be cancer. Most women experiencing the symptoms you present do NOT have cancer, but with your past history, your concern that this might be cancer certainly is valid and should not be dismissed out of hand.  I recommend that you request a mammogram, or an MRI of your breasts. The specialist may say there is no need for a mammogram - tell him you want one anyway, that with your past history you have a very valid concern about cancer, and that you want the test so you can make sure.  If he will not order it, find another dr. Talk to your GP - and if your GP is still dismissing you, find another family dr, preferably one who has respect for women's health concerns. If you don't have health insurance, check to see if your community has an organization that will pay for mammograms for women, or contact the Susan G. Komen Foundation - they will pay for mammograms for women who have health concerns.  Check to see if there is a naturopathic dr in your area that is willing to see you - this might be a naturopath, a homeopath or an osteopath.  They generally are more receptive to women's concerns and may be able to help with realistic treatment to help get your pain resolved, rather than dismissing you out of hand. Pain in the breast is usually NOT cancer (it can be cancer, and that is why I recommend a mammogram, but it usually isn't cancer.)  Pain in the breast usually is from one of three causes:  cyclical pain - which would be related to the hormone cycle, non-cyclical pain which means there is something else going on in the breast itself, and non-breast origin pain - which means the pain is being caused somewhere else but is being felt in the breast.  I'm going to talk briefly about all 3 causes, in hopes of helping you make some sense of what's happening. Cyclical breast pain correlates to women's productive hormone cycle. For some women, the closer they get to ovulating, the worse their breasts hurt, then once their period starts the pain subsides. You did not say whether or not your ovaries were removed when they did your hysterectomy.  If they were, then this simply cannot be cyclical breast pain for you. If you still have one or both ovaries, it very well could be hormone related pain, but it would still go in the cycle I described, and it sounds like that is not the case with you. Noncyclical breast pain is not hormone related but definitely does reflect a mechanical (physical) problem in the breast. Quite often these problems get labelled "fibrocystic disease" (as the 2nd dr has done with you) - and the issue never gets properly diagnosed and treated. Fibrocystic disease, fibrocystic breasts - these are all waste-basket terms, which means basically the people using them don't really know what is going on, don't know how to treat it, and throw a nonsense label on it and tell people it will go away, which is really a bunch of B.S. (The label of fibrocystic breasts is as often used with cyclical breast pain as is is with noncyclical breast pain.) Noncyclical pain isn't influenced by menses - it stays put regardless of the time of month.  It usually is in just one area - you can pinpoint exactly where it hurts. If some kind of trauma has occured to the breast, it can cause substantial pain that takes a long time to heal.  If there is a milk duct or other gland that is blocked or infected, it can cause very specific pain. There are other causes, and sometimes the cause is never known. This is why a mammogram is recommended - it is the easiest way to locate an anatomical problem in the breast, and much more accurate than manual exam. The third type of pain is called non-breast origin pain.  That means something somewhere else has gone wrong, but you feel the pain as if it was in the breast. Costochondral junction syndrome is non-breast origin pain.  Basically the dr is saying that he thinks there is a problem where there ribs bones meet the sternum (the breast bone), but he doesn't know what it is, and perhaps doesn't really care, cause he thinks it will resolve by itself.  Usually costochondral pain is arthritis in the breast bone. If you push down on the breast bone where the ribs are, and that makes it hurt a whole lot more, you probably have arthritis. Or if you take a really deep breath and it makes the middle part of your breast hurt, you probably have arthritis. If aspirin or Advil (Motrin) or Alleve make the pain go away, you probably have arthritis. Arthritis in the breast bone is usually temporary and will go away - it may take a while, but usually over time will resolve.  Aspirin, advil, alleve - over the counter anti-inflammatory drugs are usually sufficient for the pain and to help resolve the problem.  If not, the dr might be able to inject a shot of steroid into the area to help alleve the pain and resolve the condition. Yet you've got another thing that is of concern:  discharge from your nipple over a long period of time, a lymph node that is obviously overwhelmed trying to remove some kind of toxin from the breast, and pain and swelling that seems to be associated with the nipple and has gotten worse over time.  The GP putting you on antibiotics is actually a quite reasonable choice, but since it didn't help, the antibiotics either weren't the right drug, or there is no infection. Collecting a sample of the discharge for culture and sensitivity would show if there is infection and which antibiotic would be appropriate. If that wasn't done, I would ask your GP if he will order it. Possible that you do have an actual physical problem there in the breast, other than infection.  Did the specialist actually look at the discharge?  Did he take a sample of it for any testing?  At the very least, it needs to be tested for the presence of blood - which can very easily be done in the dr's office with a hemacult kit . They should do a PAP smear of the discharge (just like they do PAP smears of the cervix - it's quite accurate), and have it sent to the lab to check for abnormal cells.  Even though you saw a "specialist", it doesn't sound like this person did enough to find out why you are having these problems.  Yes, women do normally have discharge from their nipples - but usually it's from both nipples, and not for this long a continuous period of time.  Yes, womens nipples do itch - and there are lots of reasons that can happen - but when the itching is associated with pain, heat and swelling, it usually indicates something physically abnormal going on in the breast.  If it were me in this situation, I think I'd get another opinion. (I hate to sound sexist, but I definitely would be seeking an opinion from a female dr, as many times male drs just don't seem to understand how vital of a concern this can be.) I also recommend that you try to get a look at, and possibly purchase, 2 excellent books.  Dr Susan Love is one of the world's foremost medical experts on breast health.  Her book, Dr Susan Love's Breast Book (4th ed) is considered by many women to be THE Bible on breast health.  Susun Weed is an expert on herbal and nutritional health. I highly recommend her book, Breast Cancer? Breast Health! The Wise Woman Way.  I wish you the best in getting some more satisfactory answers. Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: On 8/9/2008 Addiebelle wrote: I am new to this site and have been reading about different medical subjects.I had a masectomy 2 years and 3 mo.s ago. I had chemo and radiation.I contracted shingles after three mo.s and still have them over a year later.They are very painful and there is nothing that I have found to treat them.I take lyrica for the pain but it has a lot of side effects.Does anyone know of anything that will give relief from this.I am thinking of trying acupunture. Addiebelle Hi Addiebelle, Sorry you are having such a persistent problem - shingles is very painful - you must be about ready to pull your hair out. If the Lyrica hasn't helped you by now, it's most likely not going to. And you're right - it does have a lot of side effects, and for that reason  I question that it's the best choice for your immune system right now. Shingles is caused by varicella zoster - the same virus that causes chicken pox. Once we get it, it's very difficult to kill.   Most people will  always have it, but most of the time it goes into hiding in the spinal tract. When an area along the skin nerve tracts becomes weakened and not well protected by the immune system, then it comes out and attacks again. Your cancer woke it up, although your immune system may still have been strong enough to prevent a full-fledged outbreak.  Surgery, chemo and radiation - probably all combined to weaken your immune system sufficiently that you started breaking out, and it sounds like you just aren't recovering well enough from those things to put the virus back into remission or kill it. So, an antiviral and probably all the other stuff you've been using isn't going to work.   You need to fight this virus off from the inside out - that means through immune system support.  I recommend you take a look at this olive leaf tea - it will attack the virus, and hopefully kill it, or at the very least, put it back into remission. It will build up your immune system at the same time, helping you to recover from all the treatment, plus the debilitation caused by the shingles and pain. I'm giving you both the link to the tea, and to the olivus home page, so you can look at their other products.  http://www.olivetea.com/shingles_information.htm http://www.olivus.com/conditions_olive_leaf.htm It will take a few days for shipping of the tea, and probably another few days for it to work.  In the meantime, if you haven't tried Zostrix for pain, it would be worth giving a whirl.  It's a pain reliever for arthritis, but it works very well for nerve pain caused by shingles. You can get it over the counter at your local drugstore - you may have to ask the pharmacist to help you locate it.  If the zostrix doesn't help,  message me back and I will try to find a strong herbal analgesic for you. (You can get a free sample of zostrix from this site - again, it will take a few days for shipping, but if you can't get it at the pharmacy - you can send for it online) : http://www.zostrix.com/pages/samples.asp I recommend two other things for immediate boost of your immune system, that will both help fight cancer and the virus: selenium supplement - at least 200 mcg/day - safe to take up to 400 mcg/day, but I would recommend the higher dose for a limited time only (probably not more than a week, then  drop down to the loser dose.)  You can take the selenium every day for a long time, at least until you are seeing a lot of evidence that you are finally recovering from the chemo and radiation.  selenium is a trace element that our bodies need - unlikely that you will have any problems taking it, unless you know you are allergic to it. The other supplement is zinc - 50 mg/day - TAKE IT WITH FOOD or it will upset your stomach.  Again, you can take this supplement every day for as long as it takes to get you feeling well again.  (Nutrition sites will recommend you take that high a dose of zinc only for a  limited time period, but I know of more than a few people who have taken 50 mg of zinc every day for years and years and never had a problem with it.) If you do try the accupuncture, I would still recommend immune system support, with at least the selenium and zinc. Sounds like you need to do something proactive to not just get rid of the shingles, but also to give your body a big boost to get back to normal. Good luck - I wish you well. Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: On 7/9/2008 tomslady wrote: I have recently been dx with invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast. Had the lumpectomy and setinal lobe disection last week and now have to wait until next week and meet with the oncologist to find out what the next step is going to be. My husband has been very supportive through all this but i feel guilty putting him through this. We have been married just over a year and now all this. I don't know that I want to go any farther with treament. I have been cut open 4 times in the last 6 weeks and I am feeling very sick when i look at my scares, I know they are new and they will fade but right now I cannot even look at myself in the mirror without wanting to scream.  Intamacy has become a thing if the oast since all this has started and I think that is the hardest part of all this, I need to feel close to my husband, i need hito touch me and love me the way he used to before I got sick. How so I relay this to him without pushing him. It is going to happen sooner then later that I will not physically be able to love him and feel close to him but now while I can he is scared. Does anyone have any advice for me or encouraging words of wisdom. I need something to hold on to right now.  Thanks for listening. Dear Tomslady, Let me encourage you to stand back for a few moments and take a few very deep breaths. REMEMBER: you have not been too long ago diagnosed with a very scary and threatening condition, you have had 4 surgeries in 6 weeks, and you are under extreme stress trying to cope with the change in your body image and about the need for further treatment. This is a crazy-making situation, and right now is probably NOT a good time for  you to be making the kind of decisions you are talking about.  While everything may seem to be happening so fast that you can't keep up, and your health situation may seem to be running away with of a mind of its own, but that doesn't have to be true. Yes, I know there MUST be some actions taken soon, but you are not likely to expire immediately if you first take some time to get ahold of your thoughts and emotions so that later on you can make calm, rational and well-informed decisions.  The best thing you can do for yourself and your family right now is give yourself permission to grieve for what you've just lost, determine to be kind to yourself in facing what lies ahead, and just plain give yourself some time to be still. About your specific issues: #1: don't feel guilty about "putting your husband through this."  You didn't choose to have this cancer, and your husband agreed to take on your problems as his own when he married you, so YOU aren't putting HIM through anything. You are still two individual people, but as husband and wife you are one unit, and if you allow him to support you more (as it sounds he is willing to do), as time goes on this adversity may very well serve to help you become even more unified.  (What doesn't break you, makes you stronger.) #2: continuing with treatment.  The lady who wrote and said of course you must continue with treatment is right.  You have a lot to live for, but you are overwhelmed by all this right now, and fear and pain and grief are talking for you and taking over the conversation.  That is a natural reaction, but does not have to be a permanent condition.  Again, step back, take some deep breaths, and give yourself time to regain your equilibrium.  When you are able to do that, if you would care to private message me, I will be happy to talk with you about treatment options your oncologist may or may not recommend.  (I am a former RN, and I am also a 2-time cancer survivor diagnosed with metastatic breast disease just as I was reaching the magic 5 year mark.  Traditional cancer medicines make me extremely ill, so I am using other methods to beat this thing, and I'm doing well.  I never try to discourage people from traditional treatments, but I do encourage them to use complementary therapies to add more weapons to their arsenal that they use to fight this fight.) #3:  about your breast and your surgical scars:  many, many women feel the same way you do when this happens to them.  If you can't look at yourself in the mirror right now, don't push it.  step back, take some deep breaths, and give it time. Society has done a major injustice to women by conditioning them to believe their appearance determines their worth, especially their breasts. YES, physical appearance is part of desire, but I doubt you and your husband got married believing that both would always and forever continue to look exactly like you did the day you got married.  You just thought the change would take years, and now you've been thrown a loop by having this change come so rapidly.  Again, your grief and emotions are controlling the conversation - in time that should change; indeed you must make it change. In the meantime, try giving your husband more credit on this issue, and let him prove you right in doing so. Maybe he IS scared to touch you - that's normal ( after all, YOU are scared to touch you right now.)   He might be afraid of hurting you.  He probably is acutely aware of your discomfort about the disruption in your relationship and the changes to your body, and he may not know how to start to fix things. So, you will have to learn together how to make things better. You might start by giving him a chance just to see your body again. Just let him look at your breast and ask whatever questions  are on his mind,  like, "does that hurt?"  Answer him truthfully.  Hopefully your incisions are healed enough by now that once you are comfortable with him looking at your scars,  you can then encourage him to touch them lightly, gently, with the understanding that at least for the first few times, it's just about touching, about getting used to the way things feel now.  This gives you BOTH the opportunity to learn about the way things are now without feeling pressured to do more than just look and touch. Most women who've had mastectomies have at least some small areas of numbness.  If you do, too, tell him.  Help him to understand that if you don't respond the same way physically as you used to when he touches certain areas of your breast, it's not cause you don't like his hands, but because you don't feel them.  Encourage him to touch both breasts, gently.  Gentle touch to the scars will stimulate circulation and promote healing, while gentle touch to the other side should reassure you that you are still a woman, still have feelings, and that being touched can still be a pleasurable intimate experience for both of you. Most of all, as with time things progress past this point,  make your husband feel valued - show him that you DO need him.  Men not only want to be wanted, they need to be needed. I hope that as least some small part of this helps.  And as I said earlier, if you feel you'd like to hear my thoughts on therapy, once you've had a chance to get your mind together and start to consider options, please private message me and let me know what you're thinking and feeling and considering, and I will be happy to respond, see if I can be of some help. Be kind to yourself. Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: On 7/16/2008 Pat52 wrote: I was diagnosed with DCIS, stage 1 breast cancer in April of 2006. I had 2 lumpectomies in May and 30 radiation treatments that summer.  From 9/06-6/06, I took arimidex, as recommended by my oncologist.  Weight gain, fatigue, and especially nausea with vomiting were my symptoms during that whole period.  I took myself off of it, but my oncologist convinced me to try aromasin beginning in Dec. of 07.  I have been taking it for 7 months now, and I've never felt so bad daily for so long before.  My first trigger finger developed while on the aromosin.  I have had 2 cortisone shots to help temporarily and only slightly relieve that one.  I have same digit, middle finger, on right hand now, with very limited movement and lots of pain. The pain and stiffness in both hands and feet, is probably the most debilatating symptom for me.  I have trouble walking and using my hands normally.  I too, am so stiff after sitting for even a few minutes or when getting up in the morning, I feel like someone might feel at 100 years old.  My arms and legs hurt, as do my rib area and hips at times.  I go back to my oncologist for a regular check-up in a week, but I am quitting the aromasin TODAY!  My mammogram recently came back clear.  I don't know about the bloodwork yet, until my appt.  My fingers are so swollen.  I am CONSTANTLY tired, regardless of how much sleep I get, which has been about 8-9 hours a night this summer, since I am a teacher.  I rarely have any energy to do anything, but force my self too.  But I also find myself on the couch much of the time, if I really don't HAVE to do anything.  I hate being and feeling like this.  I will post another message in a few weeks to reflect on what I notice about being off the meds.  I'm 52, going on 92! Hi Pat, You are not alone in either the symptoms you are experiencing, or in your decision to go off the medication.  If you have a little bit of time, go back through some of the earlier posts on this message board about aromasin, arimidex, tamoxifen, etc.  In addition to seeing women talk about how bad these meds made them feel, you will also find posts chock full of answers about things that will alleviate side effects, and help in the battle against cancer. I myself am a survivor of breast cancer (2002), and more recently diagnosed with metastasis to the lungs.  I did not do tamoxifen or arimidex after my surgeries, chemo and radiation (which I quit halfway through due to lymphedema) because they made me sick after just a few doses, and I chose immediate quality of life now rather than the not-guaranteed possibility of quantity of life later.  While I didn't quite make it the magic 5 years before we found the nodules in my lungs (last fall), I don't regret those choices in the least little bit.  They were the best 5 years of my life, and part of the reason is because I wasn't letting treatment make me sick. After surgical biopsy of one of the lung nodules, I was officially diagnosed with mets in Feb this year, I once again had to make treatment choices.  I took 2 doses of the Aromacin - just that little made me extremely ill, so I said "No more.  I'm not being sick like this." My lung nodules were very small, and the oncologist said I had lots of time before we needed to consider chemo, so I did a lot of research and designed my own herbal/supplemental and nutritional food regimen for fighting cancer, and it is working. I also became vegetarian and am concertedly working at losing weight (which I badly need to do.) My PET scan in June was great - some small areas of concern, but overall both the oncologist and radiologist said from that scan they cannot say that the nodules represent cancer. My blood chemistries and cell counts are fantastic - better than they've been in at least 20 years, and the cancer marker I had drawn last week is down despite the fact I haven't had chemo or prescription treatment. And I feel great!   There are herbs and natural treatments that can help you regain your health, put the side effects of aromasin behind you.  My best recommendation is that you see a certified naturopath for help with this process.  A registered nutrionist or a well-respected herbalist could help if you don't have access to a naturopathic, homeopathic, osteopathic or wholistic doctor.  If you need help with this from the message board, I myself, and some of the other frequent responders could help, but I highly recommend that you check our for yourself (through internet research, herb books, persons in the community knowledgable about natural therapies)  advice anyone on the board gives before  trying it for yourself. Not only can herbs, natural foods, alternative and/or complementary therapies help you get over the nastiness of the Aromasin, they can help you continue your fight against cancer.  Right now you appear to be cancer free - sure would be nice to keep it that way without having to suffer the pain and indignities of conventional treatments.  If you are interested in learning what you can do for yourself to prevent the cancer from coming back, I offer the same recommendations as for getting over the side effects. (There are other things to explore - ayurvedic tradition, traditional chinese medicine, diet and exercise, accupunture...) If you are interested in learning more about natural alternatives to conventional prescription treatment, feel free to send me your questions in a private message, and I will try to help you find the answers that are right for you.  Or post your questions publicly on this message board - lots of other people here that can get you started in a direction other than pain and suffering while recovering from the aromasin. I hope this answer has helped, and I wish you the best of health in the months to come. Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: there was an excellent suggestion about this problem on the message board within the last month or so.  I don't know if I will be able to find that post, but I can try. In the meantime, you can help restore the health of vaginal tissues by applying a tiny amount of flax seed oil once a day.  Just use enough to cover the pad of your finger, and gently rub it in actually up inside the vagina as well as on the outside.  Use food grade flax seed oil with lignans - keep unused oil refrigerated as it will go rancid otherwise.  Within a few days or a week you should really start to notice a big difference in these tissues - a replenishment of moisture and return of elasticity.  Once you notice a difference, decrease the frequency of the flax oil.  I am post-menopausal and have been on a natural anti-estrogen regimen - have got my estradiol level WAAAAY low - whereas at first I had to use it every day, I now only need the flax oil once every two or three weeks. Don't worry about the phytoestrogen content - this tiny amount of flax oil will help locally but is not enough to be absorbed systemically and cause a problem with cancer. It also has the advantage of being inexpensive - you can get a bottle of Barlean's organic brown flax seed oil with lignans for about $9. It will last a VERY long time.  Look in the refrigerator section at a health food store to find it.  If it's uncomfortable to do this treatment at first - if those tissues are really dry and fragile they may need more lubrication than you will get from a tiny amount of flax oil alone - you can mix 1/2 tsp flax oil with a TBSP or two of vaseline, and apply as big a dab as you need.  Do not refrigerate this mixture - it will stay good for about a week to 10 days, as long as you keep it in a clean air tight container and away from heat and light.  If the oil seperates from the vaseline, just stir with a q-tip before applying.  Once you've rejuvenated your natural tissues, something as simple as KY jelly may be adequate to allow for an enjoyable times with your partner. Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: On 6/26/2008 Kittycath wrote: I am thrilled to report that I am going to be taking my last tomaxifen in mid- August.  With family and firends we are having a PINK PARTY and I will take that last pill served on a silver platter and down it with pink champagne; everyone is going to wer pink--I am SO excited.  But--on to my questions.  I have read things here and there that soy is a No-No for breast cancer gals.  How dangerous is it to use soy?  I have put whey protein in my morning oatmeal for a couple of years, but it seems I may be having some difficulties eating so much dairy.  So, I have wondered if it would be dangerous to use soy protein instead of whey.  I use the protein powder because I am not much of a meat eater.  Also, what about body lotions containing soy (that certainly has become a trend).  Finally, what about soy "milk" like SILK?  Any nutritionists out there that can help with this? Hi Kittycath, Congratulations on your great news! Avoiding phytoestrogens altogether and maintaining a healthy diet, including foods with high anti-oxidant value, is practically impossible.  However, there is a difference in many foods, herbs, and supplements as to the strength of the phytoestrogen they contain.    I have read some pretty respectable research indicating that very strong phytoestrogens will be utilized for growth by estrogen-positive cancers, whereas very weak phytoestrogens will act as estrogen-blockers, just as tamoxifen and arimidex do.  And there are many herbs, supplements and natural foods that are natural aromatase inhibitors, which is what Aromasin and many of the newer drugs do.  SOY is one of the strongest phytoestrogens you will find in naturally occuring foods. (This includes raw soy, soy supplements, tofu, tempeh, and , soy sauce, and soy flour. Soybean oil is possibly the least of these villains, as many products with soy oil have such small amounts e.g. breads with soy oil might be ok, breads with soy flour would be a no-no.)   Yams and red clover are also very powerful phytoestrogens, and probably not good choices for anyone with active estrogen-positive breast cancer or a history of estrogen-positive breast cancer. while there is a huge on-going debate about whether wine prevents or causes cancer, there is creditable evidence that for pre-menstrual women, a small daily intake of red wine (not to exceed 3 - 4 oz) and help prevent or fight breast cancer.  Red wine is very high in resveratrol and flavonoids - that combination allows red wine to act as both a natural estrogen-blocker and an aromatase inhibitor.  Grapes, especially red grapes with the seeds in them, are showing excellent results in alternative prevention and treatment of cancer, (or grape seed extract) -  again because they act as both an estrogen-blocker and aromatase inhibitor.  White button mushrooms are also being used with good results in this particular research.   Some time spent in internet research should be fruitful at revealing other nutritious foods that are low-strength phytoestrogens and therefore can be used as natural estrogen blockers. As for avoiding soy and still eating healthy - yes, it is absolutely possible. I do it, and I eat very well.  Being vegetarian helps.  The suggestion of using brown rice milk is excellent - you can make your own inexpensively, and it keeps well in the fridge.  A little vanilla gives it flavor.  (send me a private message if you want my recipe)  Of course, check labels - the only commercially prepared product I consume with soy is 2% or less soybean oil, in bread only.  Virgin coconut oil (expeller pressed from fresh coconut meat) is an excellent choice for cooking, baking, salad dressing, etc - expensive, but using it really makes it easy to avoid soy and the other oil products that are strong on the phytoestrogen range. Infrequent consumption of some soy is probably not going to cause much harm, especially if your diet is high in anti-oxidants, and you counter the soy consumption with natural estrogen-blockers  or other foods or supplements that are showing creditability in preventing or fighting cancer.  (the old saying an apple a day - has a lot of truth to it. very dark chocolate is also our friend!!!)  I love the chinese food prepared at a local authentic chinese restaurant. I eat there every week or two, knowing that soy is a staple of their sauces.  I make sure to also take the herbs and eat the foods I am using to counter estrogen, and my estradiol level is now the lowest it has been since we started tracking it.  I hope this helps.  Again, congrats on no longer having to take that nasty medicine, and I wish you the best of luck! Sincerely, tre

Posts.Content: On 4/20/2009 l1624 wrote: Hi, I was just diagnosed with DCIS in both left and right breasts.  However, DCIS is in 2 different quartdrants of one breast.  I'm trying to decide which approach is best for the long term.  Lumpectomry/radiation + tamoxifen or simple mastectomy.  I'm afraid of the side effects of radition such as damages to lungs, hearts and ribs.  For those of you who have a similar case like me, would you please share your experience with me?  BTW, my HER-2 is negative. Thanks in advance NL     I would not do the radiation - too much risk to the heart and lungs.  Tamoxifen causes lots of problems for many women. There are natural ways to inhibit estrogen - pls see my blog: my story http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/08/my-stor my regimen http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/09/my-pers Research has shown that many people who do not seek treatment for their cancers live just as long (or longer) as people who have surgery and get chemo/radiation.  Unfortunately I do not know any way to predict who might fit in that category. There is also some concern that surgery may seed cancer to other places, but many people do not accept that this could be possible. And many leading advocates of alternative medicine can point to evidence that tumors do not have to be removed for therapy to be successful in eradicating the cancer, especially if it has been caught early.  So to me the question of surgery vs no surgery is a toss-up. (I did not even consider alternative therapies with my first diagnosis in 2002 - have learned a WHOLE lot more about them since my recurrence was diagnosed in 2008.)  If it were me, and I chose surgery, I think I would have bilateral simple mastectomy, and I would at least consider having flap reconstruction instead of implants.  But I certainly would also give serious consideration to using natural therapy either in addition to conventional treatment. or an alternative to the tamoxifen and radiation.  Many foods, herbs and supplements really can be very effective at fighting cancer as well as boosting the immune system. If you are interested in learning  more about alternatives other than the info in my blog, these are excellent sites:  http://www.cancertutor.com http://www.lefcancer.org http://alkalizeforhealth.net http://alternativecancer.us If you want to try some supplements, many leading advocates recommend at the very least taking these 5 minerals, and I recommend adding a vitamin:  selenium:  200 mcg/day (can start with 400mcg/day but only for a few weeks) magnesium:  200 - 250 mg/day (350 mg/day max), take with food zinc:  50 mg/day (can start with 100mg/day but only for a few weeks), take with food manganese: 10 - 15 mg/day, take with food calcium: 1200 mg/day We need Vitamin D-3 to be able to absorb and utilize calcium. Our bodies manufacture D-3 if we get adequate sunlight (15 - 20 minutes exposure/day) - but I do not believe in leaving this to chance, so also recommend a Vitamin D-3 supplement, 1000 - 2000 iu/day (10,000 iu/day max) I hope this reply has helped, and I wish you the very best as you make your decisions and move ahead with treatment. Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: Hi Pat, I sent you a very long private reply, detailing my personal regimen. However, I forgot to address things you can do now to get over the side effects of the aromasin and arimidex. Basically, the symptoms you had are from estrogen-depletion, a chemically induced menopause, if you will.  While almost everyone agrees that taking actual estrogens when you have estrogen-receptor positive breast cancer is a big no-no, there is a huge raging debate about the advisability of ingesting phytoestrogens (plant estrogens.)  Almost every source I've seen says to avoid soy, because it is such a strong phytoestrogen, but that may not be true.  I think the jury will be out on that one for a long, long time.  In the meantime, maybe best to avoid soy. Emerging research is indicating that foods/supplements comprising strong phytoestrogens will feed estrogen-dependent cancer,  while those with weak phytoestrogens can act as aromatase inhibitors and estrogen-blockers.  There are a lot of weak phytoestrogens in the regimen I am using, but you need something that will take hold much faster.  Flax oil pressed without the hulls is probably not a good choice, but flax seeds and flax oil with the hulls (lignans) could be really helpful to you right now to get over the aromasin and arimidex.  This website does a pretty good job of explaining the benefits of lignan: http://www.wildernessfamilynaturals.com/high_lignan_flax.htm You don't have to buy the product they are promoting on the web page, but please do read the information.  They mention the Budwig diet, which focuses on flax seed and cottage cheese. I haven't studied Budwig in-depth, therefore cannot recommend or speak against it as an alternative treatment for cancer, but I do feel that you should take a look at it, as following it at least for a week or two may help get your body back on track.  You can get organic flax seed at just about any health food store, and you can add it to cottage cheese whole or you can grind it slightly to break up the hulls and make the lignam more easily digestible.  I really would recommend referring to the Budwig diet for amounts.  You could take flax oil with lignan if you don't want to do the seeds/cottage cheese - I would have to do more research before I could recommend how much. Also might be helpful to look at these resources: http://www.susanlovemd.com/    (she has an excellent book:  "Dr Susan Love's Breast Book, 4th ed.") "Prescription for Nutritional Healing" by Phyllis Balch - it's wonderful but expensive, so if you can get to a good bookstore that has it, take a pen and notepad and take notes rather than buy the book  Since a lot of your symptoms involve joint pain, you might also consider taking an herbal preparation specific for arthritis for a month or so.    Garlic supplement, boswellia, lots of green onions (as food), b-vitamins, maybe curcumin (turmeric spice) - these are things that should help.  Get plenty of calcium and vitamin c, as well as vit D and E.  You might try homeopathic remedy tablets for under the tongue - rhus toxicodendron (do NOT use if severe allergy to poison oak), arnica montana, and/or bryonia alba: used as directed on the label, take in a clean mouth (no food or liquids),  take only one type at a time, wait at least 15  - 30 minutes before taking another type.  Check at a health food store or herb shop near you - they should have these things. The papaya, bromelain and mulberry that I mentioned in my private message  are excellent choices, too, and will help to fight against cancer as well as getting over the meds.  Papaya and bromelain are easily available at GNC or health food stores.  THe mulberry you will have to get from swansonvitamins.com I hope this helps - sure would be nice to hear you say you are feeling better! sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: Sounds like the dr just wasn't being very articulate.  You may have a low risk of breast cancer based on personal and family history, but he probably meant that the microcalcifications are an indicator that needs to be checked out, rather than an increased risk.  many women have biopsies done based on the evidence of finding microcalcifications, and many of these women have benign findings.  But it is good to have it checked out, anyway. Keep busy while waiting for a biopsy date, and then waiting for that date to arrive and the biopsy report after that.  Turn your nervous energy into a good opportunity to get things done around the house, get some exercise, etc.  And make sure to do some fun things, too - that will help you to relax. Hope everything turns out ok. Tre
Posts.Title: Confused and waiting

Posts.Content: There are some research studies indicating that anti-estrogen drugs (both estrogen-blockers such as Tamoxifen and aromatase inhibitors such as Arimidex and Aromatase) lose their effectiveness within 3 1/2 to 4 years. So were it me, I would not stay on it past 5 years. If you are worried about recurrence of cancer even after 5 years of being on Arimidex, there are many things you can do naturally to minimize the risk of recurrence. Many of these things address the immune system and maintaining an internal enviroment that is non-condusive to cancer; there are things you can do with diet, herbs, and supplements to specifically maintain low estrogen levels so as to deprive nourishment to any remaining cells. I designed an effective natural regimen for myself when diagnosed with metastasis to the lungs (I do NOT tolerate the anti-estrogen drugs.)  My estrogen level was in the 20's a year ago, it is now below 5. I do not recommend anyone else try to design their own regimen unless they have sufficient medical or health care background to really know what they are doing, but I DO recommend that anyone interested in continuing an anti-estrogen lifestyle AFTER treatment with Arimidex, etc, consult a naturopathic/holistic professional for advice on how to initiate and maintain self-treatment. I have published my personal anti-cancer regimen on my blog.  I do not offer it as a prescription for anyone - everyone's body chemistry is different, so not everything that works for me is going to work for someone else; rather I  offer the regimen as an example of those things that people fighting cancer or seeking to stay cancer free can do simply and inexpensively, in concert with personalized recommendations by a professional.  Please feel free to look at my blog - you will find my story there, as well as many other articles that might be of interest.   http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/09/my-pers There are also great web sites that give information on alternative methods of preventing recurrence, including supplementation and anti-cancer diets. these are the best I've found: www.cancertutor.com www.lefcancer.org www.alkalizeforhealth.net I hope this helps. Sincerely, Tre
Posts.Title: Arimidex--stay on or quit?

Posts.Content: Fat tissue certainly can die as a result of radiation - either due to injury to the tissue from the radiation itself, or having the blood supply to the tissue cut off because of the radiation. Some who have necrosis of adipose suffer no ill effects - it  eventually liquefies and reabsorbs, and the area fills in with new healthy tissue.  The big risk, however, is of abscess and/or infection - as a nurse I took care of a few people who had to deal with this, and it wasn't fun. Thus you are wise to keep seeking until you find help. Also, ask your dr about the pathology report on the core biopsy.  Are they absolutely sure that the necrotic tissue is adipose, and not dead cancer cells? Necrotic cancer cells also will usually reabsorb over time, without ill effects, but it's important to differentiate whether these are dead normal cells or part of a tumor that died.  If there's any doubt that they might be tumor cells, you will want to make sure there is no evidence of live cells in the surrounding area.  (PET scan might or might not be a good choice for this - if there is inflammation or infection, the scan might show a false positive.) OK - I've not seen any messages about this subject on Cancer Compass in the past 8 - 9 months, but then I haven't seen every message on the board, either.  If you don't get any other responses to your query, you might try doing an internal search on CC to see if there are any past message threads that would have answers for you.  Check for cancers other than breast cancer - radiation can kill off adipose tissue in ANY part of the body, and necrotic adipose tissue might actually be more common in radiation of stomach and colon cancers. I imagine subsequent treatment would be much the same regardless of location.  Other resources you might try are www.drsusanloveresearchfoundation.org and http://ww5.komen.org/ (the Susan Komen foundation).  They might have information on this, or you might try sending them an email asking if they can direct you to someone for treatment.  I believe there is a "contact us" link on both sites. I wish you good luck in getting answers, and hope that this turns out to be nothing more than a temporary concern! Sincerely, Tre
Posts.Title: side effects from mamma site radiation

Posts.Content: Hi Ninasuzie, I'm sorry you had to join this club.  Scary and disheartening stuff, that's for sure.  I am a big advocate of breast conservation for most women, but invasive cancer can be quite a different beast.  While they can't accurately stage the cancer until the surgery, were they able to grade it based on the biopsy, and have they been able to say how aggressive they think it is?  With staging, the lower the number the better, but with grading, the opposite is true - the higher the grade number the better.  So, if this is a not very aggressive cancer with a higher grade, you might be ok with a very thorough lumpectomy.  However, if this is aggressive (as it might be - 4.5 cm is a pretty big tumor) and/or low grade, you might do well to consider telling them to just take the whole thing so as to maximize the chances of removing all the cancer.  (Also, consider - if the margins AREN'T clear when they do the path exam of tissue from  your lumpectomy - as happened with me - you're gonna have to have a 2nd surgery anyway, at which time they may or may not be able to conserve remaining breast tissue, depending upon the location of the tumor in the breast.) I think societies through out the ages have done women a HUGE disservice to place so much emphasis on the breasts in terms of what constitutes attractiveness and social worth.   Breasts play such a huge role for many women in terms of self image, but I think that's a learned process rather than a trait we are born with.   While our breasts are indeed part of WHAT we are, they really are not WHO we are; WHO we perceive ourselves to be results from the very active decisions we make about how to respond to the world around us. Consider the great women of our time, some of whom are (or were) actually quite flat-chested (and no, I'm not just talking about Twiggy!  Katherine Hepburn, yes!) They forged ahead with life regardless of how much padding they did or didn't have! To combine the comments of two other frequent posters to the board:  They're just boobs.  You can replace the girls, but you can't replace your life! I wish you the best in making this tough decision, and in your treatment.  Please keep us posted on how you are doing.  Cancer Compass is one of the greatest clubs in the world - we collectively try to support those in need, and we all love to do the happy dance when we hear good news! Take care,  Tre
Posts.Title: Experiences with breast surgery and chemo options

Posts.Content: I can empathize with both you and your mother, having helped my mother in her battle with multiple myeloma, then years later being diagnosed and treated for breast cancer myself. Life can land some incredibly cruel blows. If I've learned anything from the hard blows life has dealt me, it is to just keep faithfully plugging away at the tough stuff until I can find a way to turn adversity to advantage. Once I've found that turning point, I know the battle is mine.  I don't necessarily focus on winning the war - today has enough trouble of its own without borrowing from tomorrow - but I sure do fight hard to win every battle.  Sounds like you  have that same spirit about you, and I hope your mother does also.  It will serve you well; nothing so powerful as a kick-cancer-in-the-butt attitude! I would encourage you to talk to your mother about boosting her immune system as much as she possibly can in the days leading up to surgery, chemo, radiation - whatever the treatment might be.  Lots of herbs, supplements, and natural foods available that  both build up the immune system  and fight cancer. e.g. anti-oxidants, cruciferous vegetables, fruits high in citric acid, apple cider vinegar, lots of pure water, ground brown flax seed and/or flax oil with lignins, apples and grapes (eat the seeds, too - a little bitter, but the seeds contain a natural cancer killer), papaya and bromelaine (enzymes), whole grain foods - these are all nutritious cancer killers that also play an important part in immune system health.  Both research and anecdotal experience is revealing grape seed extract as an extremely effective weapon against breast cancer, and it too works to boost the immune system. Exercise is important not just to build up her stamina and oxygenate her body, but to boost her spirits as well.  Doesn't have to be extremely strenuous, but would help to do some type of exercise 20 - 30 minutes a day, enough to release endorphins that may give her a sense of well-being that is so hard to find in times like these.  Add to that some humor, every day.  Belly laughter is extremely powerful medicine, with chuckling and smiling coming in a close 2nd and 3rd.  Especially important to maintain an active sense of humor after treatment has begun. Let us know if have questions about naturally healing foods, etc, to help your mom get ready for treatment, and to sustain her during treatment.  I'll be glad to share references and more ideas, as I'm sure will other posters on the board. I wish you and your mom the best.  Please keep us informed of your progress. Sincerely, Tre
Posts.Title: The Journey Begins

Posts.Content: If you don't have any symptoms that there is a problem in the other breast, breast exams and mammograms have been good, then I would see no reason to have more surgery.  At this point it sounds like you would be at more risk of complications caused by mastectomy (infection, poor healing, scarring, decreased flow of lymph fluids) than you are at risk of having cancer show up in the other breast. You might consider focusing your efforts on prevention through natural means. Even something as simple as supplementing with a few very basic minerals and vitamins, plus drinking plenty of fresh pure water and getting regular exercise, plus focusing as much as possible on eating raw, fresh fruits and vegetables and whole grains/legumes can make a tremendous impact on preventing cancer in someone who's already had it. Leading advocates of natural therapies recommend that at the very least people should take the following supplements (or ensure that they are getting this amount in their food):  selenium:  200 mcg/day (can start with 400mcg/day but only for a few weeks) magnesium:  200 - 250 mg/day (350 mg/day max), take with food zinc:  50 mg/day (can start with 100mg/day but only for a few weeks), take with food manganese: 10 - 15 mg/day, take with food calcium: 1200 mg/day We need Vitamin D-3 to be able to absorb and utilize calcium. Our bodies manufacture D-3 if we get adequate sunlight (15 - 20 minutes exposure/day) - but I do not believe in leaving this to chance, so also recommend a Vitamin D-3 supplement, 1000 - 2000 iu/day (10,000 iu/day max)  These are excellent sites if you want to learn more about natural treatment and prevention of cancer: http://www.cancertutor.com http://www.lefcancer.org http://alkalizeforhealth.net http://alternativecancer.us You are also welcome to look at my blog for examples of natural choices that for many people may fight and/or prevent cancer: http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/09/my-pers (There are quite a few other articles on the blog - please feel free to look through whatever interests you.) Sincerely, Tre
Posts.Title: need help with decision

Posts.Content: On 5/16/2008 Hope4vr wrote:    I need some advice. I have fybrosistic breasts and it is very difficult to notice any lumps because they are already very lumpy, but I have been told that if it is hard and pea size to check it right away. My problem is that for the past year  I have noticed my upper right armpit with lumps. They get swollen and are painful 2weeks before my period starts. After they reduce in size and but do not completely dissaper. I have informed my obgyn and family physician and both give no concern about it, they can't even feel the lumps. They just say the same thing reduce your about of coffee and caffeine, but the lumps are starting to bother me more and more and I'm getting very scared. Please any advice would be appreciated. the other replies to your message offer good advice - get it checked out, cause is could be cancer.  I would like to offer some advice you may not have already heard about the fibrocystic problem:  fybrocystic disease interferes with drainage of lymph fluid from the breasts, and this complicates things quite a bit.  Lymph drainage can be facilitated by exercising  with a mini-trampoline (or otherwise known as a rebounder.)  You can get a 36" one at a discount department store for $30 - $40 that work perfectly well for anyone up to 250 Lbs.   You don't have to do any fancy exercise on it; simply standing on it and gently bouncing without your feet leaving the mat, for 3 minutes twice a day, will help remove the lymph fluid from around the cysts in your breasts, and it may also help reduce the size and pain of the cysts themselves.  I have both lymphedema and fibrocystic breast disease.  I started exercising with a rebounder 1 week ago, and the decrease in the amount of fluid in my arm, underarm, and breasts is amazing.  I am much more comfortable, and bouncing on the rebounder is fun, once your calf muscles get over being sore!
Posts.Title: Need advice/ Fybrosistic breasts

Posts.Content: On 6/30/2008 hocema171 wrote: I was diagnosed with a very rare form of breast cancer,, invasive adnoid cycstic carcenoma. Any information would be helpful since the doctors around here have no experience of this type. I am going for a masectomy soon and I am very scared I wrote a lengthy reply to your message late last evening, but it looks like it didn't post.  I did not save the information I tried to post, but I was able to find the website address I thought you might look at: http://www.webmd.com/cancer/adenoid-cystic-carcinoma This webpage probably doesn't give as much info as you are looking for, but it does give contact information for organizations that could help you.  I highly recommend you check them out, especially the Cancer Hope Network.  Going through treatment for cancer is scary enough without having a rare type that most people don't know anything about.  These groups that are listed have people who can help you in your fight against adenoid cystic carcinoma, or else they would not be listed on this webpage. Remember, it's ok to be scared, but it's NOT ok to let your fear control you.  Seek help from whatever resources you have:  family, friends, local support groups, etc.  Ask your doctor who they would recommend locally to give you moral and emotional support and assistance such as helping with meals, or someone to go with you to chemo, etc.  Don't do this alone. Try to find humor wherever and whenever you can.  Laughter is one of the greatest weapons in the battle against disease.  And make sure to keep yourself as healthy as you can - eat lots of green leafy veggies, lots of legumes, and fresh fruit.  Drink plenty of pure water (steam distilled water is great for cleansing the body of toxins.)  Try to get some kind of exercise every day.  Fresh air and sunshine are great healers - just make sure to ask your doctor how much you can be in the sun, because some chemotherapy and radiation therapies can make you very susceptible to sunburn.  If you are an animal lover, have pets or someone you know has pets, try to spend some time with them, too.  Animals can be great at giving unconditional TLC.  My cats were a great comfort to me when I was going through multiple surgeries, chemo and radiation. And make sure you have someone to talk to, to give you a hug when you need it, and to just be there for you.  Leaning on another's strength can go a long way toward erasing fear and instilling hope and courage. If the web page I gave you doesn't help, and if others don't answer your message, keep looking on the internet, and talk to local cancer groups - they may have resources that you might not find otherwise.  I wish you the very best. Sincerely, Tre
Posts.Title: very scared about rare breast cancer

Posts.Content: Dear Songbird, If this were me, I would choose the biopsy, and have it done as soon as possible.  Needle biopsy is painful, and if you don't have insurance it will be expensive, but I'd rather go thru some pain and expense now and find it be nothing or something small,  than not find out now and possibly give cancer 6 months to grow and perhaps even spread. Early detection is so vitally important to surviving this dread disease.  You are being given a tremendous advantage if indeed this is cancer and is only in one node - please think about this very seriously before you make a decision. Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: I did not have this same type of breast cancer, but have fought breast cancer myself and put it into remission. I agree with what suzy said - keep living without looking back. (Or as the folk saying goes, "Don't let yesterday take up too much of today.") At the same time, you can't let tomorrow take up too much of today, either. What will be is in part determined by how we live right now, minute to minute, day to day. In choosing to live in the hear and now, we can be powerfully proactive toward preventing the future from mirroring the past. Find a good cancer diet chock full of fresh raw produce (organic is best) whenever possible.  Drink plenty of fresh pure water (steam-distilled or revers-osmosis filtered are best.)  Get lots of good aerobic exercise.  Make sure you are getting enough of the vitamins and minerals the body needs to maintain a healthy immune and cancer-fighting system.  Most of the leading advocates of natural/alternative therapies say there are 5 minerals that are absolutely essential to anyone trying to prevent or fight cancer, and there is one vitamin that must be added to make these minerals work: selenium:  200 mcg/day (can start with 400mcg/day but only for a few weeks) magnesium:  200 - 250 mg/day (350 mg/day max), take with food zinc:  50 mg/day (can start with 100mg/day but only for a few weeks), take with food manganese 10 - 15 mg/day, take with food calcium: 1200 mg/day We need Vitamin D-3 to be able to absorb and utilize calcium. Our bodies manufacture D-3 if we get adequate sunlight (15 - 20 minutes exposure/day) - but I do not believe in leaving this to chance, so also recommend a Vitamin D-3 supplement, 1000 - 2000 iu/day (10,000 iu/day max)  If you want to see an example of easy, inexpensive foods, herbs and supplements that can be adopted into a cancer-preventive lifestyle, please take a look at my blog:  http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/09/my-pers By no means are my blog articles the "be-all, end-all" for information - just something to give people an idea of what's available in the way of naturals to keep cancer away.  Much more valuable information to be found on the internet and in a number of excellent books that have been published on the subject. Don't just think that you don't want the beast to come back - become proactive at keeping it away. I highly recommend Dr Susan Love's Breast Book, 4th ed. by Dr Susan Love.  many women consider this to be their bible on breast health.  It is an excellent place to start for information on how to keep one's breast and body healthy. I wish you many happy cancer-free years! Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: Hi Julia, I understand your frustration, and your desire to prevent further problems, but I hope you will give consideration to some alternatives. Some clinicians are coming to suspect that surgical intervention in cancer may cause problems leading to metastasis by seeding individual tiny groups of cells from an area that has cancer to areas that don't have cancer. I have seen some research that indicates this might be possible with prophylactic mastectomy if indeed there are already precancerous cells trying to proliferate.   Here is a link to a report on breast cancer, both causes and prevention, published by AP John Cancer Institute. It's pretty informative about things that can be done to decrease the potential of proliferation of pre-cancerous cells. The second link is to their "Cancer Detox System"  - the articles are kind of technical, but I think they are plow-through-able:   http://www.apjohncancerinstitute.org/breast.htm   http://www.apjohncancerinstitute.org/cancer.htm    I am hoping you will take a look at some other resources as concerns using diet/nutrition, herbs, and supplements to boost the immune system and prevent cancer. These are two excellent resources:   http://www.cancertutor.com   http://www.lefcancer.org    Sincerely, Tre
Posts.Title: Prophylactic subcutaneous mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Jodie, I'm so sorry treatment isn't working for you. I cannot imagine how heartbroken you must have been when told this news. There is a lot of creditable evidence that as cancer metastasizes, it can also mutate and become drug resistant. Nodules in the lungs, lymph system, other organs may not have the same exact pathology as tumors in the breast, and cancer spots can exist that are too small to detect at the time of biopsy; as treatment progresses, those cancers adapt to that treatment so that while it may be effective for the original tumor or site of metastasis, over time that treatment just won't work for everything.  That may be the case with you. Unfortunately, Herceptin hasn't been in use long enough for there to be much if anything in the way  of long-term study results (10 - 20 years), especially for those who began treatment when they already had advanced disease.  That also might mean that there isn't the kind of info available on how to proceed when Herceptin fails that we would like there to be. (non-sequitor: Before I forget - just for a laugh, being bald might not be bad for a clown - you could paint funny pictures on your head!) But seriously, have you considered complementary or alternative medicine: using herbs, diet, supplements, even a more formal alternative protocol? Your dr may have some suggestions about which he/she feels hopeful (I am wondering if  Taxol will be one of them?), and if you want to keep hitting this hard with conventional treatment, then I say "Go for it." But I would encourage you to at least take a look at natural therapies.  There are things you can do in addition to  chemo, and there are treatments many people are doing instead of chemo.  I may be repeating info I've given you before, but I seriously believe in the ability of the human body to use proper amounts of natural substances to boost the immune system and to fight cancer.  Everybody's body chemistry is different, but there are some nutrients and compounds that EVERYONE needs to fight this disease, and many people just aren't getting them in sufficient quantities: e.g. selenium; zinc; vitamin c; b vitamins; the fat soluble vitamins A, D and E I posted a message to a previous herceptin thread that I'm hoping it will help you to read - my post is a few messages down the thread: http://www.cancercompass.com/message-board/message/all,27787 I very highly recommend the book I mention in the message. I also highly recommend two sites: http://www.cancertutor.com http://www.lefcancer.org You are also welcome to take a look at the herbal/supplemental/diet regimen I am using - not as a recommendation for a regimen for you (as I said, everyone's body chemistry is different - what works for me might NOT work for you, especially since our breast cancers are quite different in makeup) - but rather just to get an idea of some simple things that can be done to fight cancer nutritionally.  I am also including the link for my story - I haven't been through as tough of trials as you are now facing, but I am hoping you will take encouragement from what I have written. Feel free to explore any other posts on the blog that interest you: http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/09/my-pers http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/08/my-stor Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: Many people forego the radiation. What's most important is that you are at peace with your decision - how we feel about ourselves (the decisions we make) can either positively or negatively influence the chemical balance of our bodies, and that in turn can either work to prevent or promote cancer.  The more postively we feel about ourselves, the better our body chemistry will be. As for the Arimidex, many also forego that, or get into treatment and then decide to quit because the side effects are so bad.  But there is a way to achieve the same results as arimidex, without the side effects, and with the added advantage of being able to control just how much we estrogen deplete ourselves.  That way is through the use of natural therapy to both block estrogen reception and inhibit aromatase, just as the prescription drugs do.  Foods, plants, herbs, and some supplements contain phytochemicals - in this case the active ones we seek are phytosterols/phytoestrogens.  Weak phytoestrogens will act as estrogen blockers or aromatase inhibitors (the desired effect), whereas strong phytoestrogens will act like hormone  replacement therapy (undesired effect.)  Some naturals and supplements affect the body's production of estrogen in other ways.  e.g. plain aspirin, when used once daily as a supplement, inhibits the release of prostaglandins that are needed to produce aromatase. Very simple thing to do - take 325mg aspirin everyday. Not ALL you need to do, but when combined with other natural approaches, very effective. Estradiol is the form of estrogen that cancer uses to feed. My estradiol level was in the 20's a year ago ; with use of natural alternatives it was down below 5 about 3 weeks ago. (Which actually is TOO low - as my skin is protesting, so now I am trying to raise it just a little bit.) Mention that the brain uses estrogen also, and that the effect of arimidex, etc, on the brain has not been studied is very interesting.  The only research I have seen on this was aimed at the effects of herbs - I think specifically grape-seed extract - on estrogen production and utilization.  The study did look at cognitive effects, and did not find any deficits. As long as the body does not TOTALLY shut down production of estrogen, and as long as the naturals being used do not easily cross the blood brain barrier, it seems from this study that the effect on the brain is minimal.  (Of course very severe estrogen depletion WILL limit availability.) So it seems important to use a combination of estrogen blockers AND aromatase inhibitors - cut down some but not totally on the production of estrogen, and use estrogen blockers that do not cross the blood brain barrier but instead will block receptor sites in places such as the breast, the major organs other than the brain. I'm not saying I have a formula for doing that - but I believe it could be done. As for how I got my estradiol level so low, I have published my natural regimen on my blog - you are welcome to look at it.  I do not intend this as a prescription for anyone - everyone's body chemistry is different, and what is a good combination of naturals for me is not necessarily a good combination for someone else.  However, there are many simple and inexpensive things I do that could be of benefit to others, and I have tried to highlight them in my blog article. Please feel free to look at anything else on the blog that interests you. http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/09/my-pers Please pay attention to my recommendations on selenium, calcium, manganese, magnesium, zinc and vitamin D-3.  Many experts on alternative therapies say these elements are absolutely essential for anyone fighting cancer or trying to prevent recurrence. Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: On 7/30/2008 tracie wrote: My mom was diagnosied about a year and half about with stage 4 breast cancer.  It had also spread into both of her lungs and a spot on her spine.  She isn't on chemo or radiation, the dr has her on areida to treat the other cancer since her breast was removed.  My question is, she is complaining of terrible back pain to the point she can barely walk.  It is on one side and on her hip area too.  She just went for tests.  She said the pain feels like bones rubbing into each other.  Could this be the cancer spreading?  Trying to find what bone cancer feels like on the web isn't that easy.  Just wondering if anyone knows or has experienced anything like that.  I am scared to death.  Thank you Tracie Hi Tracie, Many, many women have severe pain with breast metastasis to the bone. In fact, because the bones are so rich in blood supply and so closely tied into the nerves, bone cancer pain can be quite severe, whether the cancer is primary or metastatic, or  very localized or more widely spread through out the bone.  Even if the metastasis is well confined to one point in your mom's back, the pain could radiate so that it seems like everything hurts. some people will have accompanying muscle spasms due to the changing calcium content in the blood stream, and that can be extremly painful, also. One of the risks of bone metastasis is osteoporosis, where the bones lose calcium, become brittle and break.  And yes, that is extremely painful also.  Hopefully the test results will be back soon, so the dr will know whether to treat with pain meds, if there is a fracture, if the Aredia is working, etc.  In the meantime, you might try to help your mom get relief from the pain through a mind technique - focusing on other things present in the here and now. (I've used this myself in a very simplified form.  I look at my cat, focusing solely on the cat, and I say either silently or aloud, "I see the cat, I hear the cat, I feel the cat." and I keep repeating that same thing over and over until the pain is either subsided enough to be bearable or even better, totally gone.) You could get more information about mind techniques like this from the internet (search items: mind techniques to manage pain, or mindfulness technique - which is a somewhat different thing,) or ask your mom's dr about a referral to a pain clinician. I am not specifically familiar with Aredia, although I do know it is being  used mostly for treatment of myeloma, and is supposed to not only slow advancement of disease, but also decrease pain and reduce fractures. Some people on it will still have bone pain due to their underlying disease - I don't know if this lasts as treatment goes on or not. If you don't get any other answers on this message board specifically addressing the Aredia, you might try posting your question on the multiple myeloma board - responders there are sure to know a lot more about the drug than I do, and they may also have suggestions on how to help your mom deal with the pain. I wish you and your mom the best. Sincerely, Tre

Tracie Hi Tracie, Glad to hear your mom is doing better. Difficult to answer your question. Did the dr actually say that there is no metastasis to the bone, or that there was but it is now  all gone? Or did he just say the bone looks better?    Could by saying that "everything is fine' he have meant that the medicine is doing what it is sposed to do, that there is no bone rubbing against bone, no broken bone, etc - that the pain is normal, to be expected from  the disease and/or the action of the medicine?   Is your mom still on the Aredia?  If so, he's still treating the bone for something, and he expects her to continue to have pain, at least for now. The fact that he did mention radiation leads me to believe he is still treating her for metastasis to the bone.  Call the dr's office and ask (mom may have to make the call if they don't have permission to give information to you.)  If they say it's NOT cancer, ask them to explain what it is, and why radiation would be appropriate if the pain meds don't work.  After all, you're paying them for information as well as treatment! Posts.Content: P.S.  i apologize if my reply was a little harsh or more graphic than seemed warranted.  Did not mean to scare anyone - but rather to say that while symptoms can be an indicator, not everyone HAS symptoms, and not everyone heeds symptoms when they have them. Indeed, a woman can go for quite a long time with cancer without knowing that anything is wrong.  My lump was quite large when I found it, but was hidden very high in the breast (almost under the armpit) and very deep within the tissues. I doubt that I ever would have found it had I not had very sudden excruciating pain when the tumor started pressing on the nerve,  and hidden so high in the breast that it was unlikely that it would have been caught on mammogram without my already knowing that it was there and being able to tell the tech that she didn't yet have enough of my breast in the machine to show the lump.  My one symptom came very late - it was already stage II when I had my surgery. That's why I encourage women not to depend upon presence or absence of symptoms when a biopsy can give them a definite answer. Best wishes to you, Tre

Posts.Content: You could indeed be having pain from the chemo, even this long afterward.  you should talk to both your oncologist and your surgeon about the pain.  However, there are many other things it could be - dr's office is a good place to start to find out why the pain.  You say your arms are not swelling, but you still could be developing lymph edema, especially if you have increased the muscular activity of your arms without making sure to take time to elevate them and let them drain.  Most sources say women with lymph edema should keep there arms elevated above shoulder level for at least 45 min twice a day - I don't know too many women who have time to do that.  Personally, I exercise with a rebounder (mini-trampoline), and I sleep with my affected arm elevated (entire arm needs to be above level of heart, with fingers highest.)   You might benefit from physical therapy by someone who specializes in post-reconstructive surgery therapeutics.   You would probably need a dr's referral for that.  Find ways to modify the strenuous tasks you must do because you have no help.  Instead of carrying one really heavy grocery bag, split it up into two lighter bags, and carry them one at a time.  Avoid plastic bags - the "handles" can really cut off circulation to the hands and fingers, and put tremendous strain on the wrists, elbows, and arms, especially if they are loaded heavily.  Cloth bags are better, paper bags are excellent because they force you to pick them up by the bottom and use better body mechanics.  You might benefit all around by finding ways to reduce stress to your upper body.  As a fitness instructor, you most likely are using your shoulder, arm and hand muscles a lot.  You may be forcing more circulation and lymph fluids into your arms than your altered drainage system can handle.  I knew I was getting lymph edema before it became physically visible because my arm and hand was starting to feel a lot different than normal, and it was starting to hurt, especially if I used that hand a lot.  With increased exercise of your arms, you might benefit by wearing compression sleeves while you are exercising.  They make some pretty light and much more comfortable sleeves these days than they used to - you just may have to do some online research to find what is right for you.  Also, find a way to frequently raise and gently - emphasis on GENTLY - shake your arms and fingers, and do GENTLE stretching of your shoulders and upper back muscles.  This will help return circulation and lymph fluids to the chest and minimize congestion in the arms/hands.  Most importantly, get it checked out by the doc/s, cause as I said earlier, there are things this could be other than recovery from chemo or lymph problem.  You may even have sustained an injury as you returned to pre-surgery routines.  Good luck.
