Posts.Content: On 10/30/2008 monique41 wrote: Hi, I had a lumpectomy last Friday and went for my post-op visit with the surgeon today.  He told me that the lymph nodes are clear of cancer but not all the tissue around the cancer in my left breast.  It is suppose to be a slow growing 1.5 cm. cancer.  I am completely shocked with the outcome. My husband and I could not believe the news, and I think the surgeon himself was a little surprised.  I am due for another surgery next week and hopefully radiation after that.  Has anyone out there had more than two lumpectomys????    I am 67 years old and still in shock.  Thanks for any info,  Monika        Hi Monika, Yes, I went through this, as have many other women.  It is not uncommon to have cancer cells in the tissue surrounding a lump.  In fact the drs expect this and generally will take a wide margin of tissue from around the lump when they remove the lump. Unfortunately, sometimes the cells have spread farther than the dr expected when he/she did the lumpectomy, and then they have to go back and remove these additional cells. This technically is not considered 2 lumpectomies, but rather a lumpectomy (medical term is "partial mastectomy") and then "revision of partial mastectomy." This does not have anything to do with how fast-growing the cancer is.  Those loose cells in the tissue surrounding the lump had probably already been there for quite some time, but not long enough to have gotten into the lymph nodes (which is GOOD - makes your prognosis better, even with having to do the revision to remove cells.) Probably the most difficult part for you, other than having to have another surgery,  will be that your drs will want to put off chemo/radiation for a while, to give you a chance to heal from the 2nd surgery. And that is really important - not only will you have a larger wound to heal, but you will have more anesthesia from which to recover. (Even though the obvious effects of anesthesia wear off quickly, it can take our bodies months to totally metabolize the drugs out of our systems - the more anesthesia we have, the longer that takes.)  Be sure to drink plenty of pure fresh water and eat lots of high antioxidant foods to help your body detoxify these chemicals.  Drinking green tea helps also. (If you have a port and are going to be on a blood-thinner, check with the doc before drinking a lot of tea, as teas prolong clotting times.) I had a hysterectomy for endometrial cancer in Mar 02. In late April, I discovered a very large lump in my breast. I had lumpectomy (partial mastectomy) in May 02.  The margins of tissue removed in that surgery showed cancer cells, and in June 02 I had revision of the partial mastectomy and removal of about half of my lymph nodes. I was not able to start chemo until July 02, and started radiation Nov 02.  I developed lymph edema and stopped the radiation mid-way thru Dec. Was a very long year for me.  Because I had had so much anesthesia plus chemo and radiation, I did not start feeling like I had any energy until Mar or April 03.  I did not supplement with vitamins, etc, and I did not push myself. for detoxification. In retrospect I think I would have done much better had I researched complementary and alternative therapies/supplementations and been much more pro-active in my recovery. I feel I might have been better able to prevent metastasis diagnosed 5 years later if I had gotten into and maintained an herbal regimen in 2002/2003, instead of waiting until the cancer had come back. If you are interested in learning about natural things you can start doing to aid in treatment and recovery, you are welcome to look at my blog.  My cancer story is there, plus my herbal/supplemental regimen  that has put my metastasis into remission. (Not a prescription for any other person, but I have tried to emphasize those things that might well help others fight their cancer.) You are welcome to look at anything else on the blog that interests you. http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/08/my-stor my regimen http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/09/my-pers I wish you the very best. Please feel free to contact me if you have other questions you feel I might be able to answer or if you just need someone with whom to talk. Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: Glad you got thru your surgery ok.  Write down any question as it pops into your mind - those are the questions you should be asking. Things you need to know: what stage and grade is the cancer?  Did they find it in lymph nodes?  How many lymph nodes if any did they remove?  Was there any muscle removed, or just breast tissue?  How long do you need to heal before further therapy?  What does the dr recommend in the way of exercises and nutrition for healing?  How fast should you be increasing your activity?  Does he expect any problems with lymphedema, and what should you be doing now to prevent it? Don't worry too much about addiction to the pain meds - you shouldn't need to be on them that long.  Especially if you get yourself up and about and moving around, and gently but persistently do your exercises to get your chest and shoulder back into normal functional shape. Gently using those muscles and keeping those tissues moving is really important toward preventing scarring that can bind up movement and cause a lot of restrictive pain later. Very gentle self-massage can also help with circulation and prevent scarring and lymphedema - but you need to know how long the dr wants you to wait before doing anything like that. Also, make sure you're drinking plenty of fluids, especially water, and eating some good roughage.  It's ok to take the pain meds if you need them, but constipation from pain pills (especially in light of just having had anesthesia) can be a problem.   Make yourself start walking outside every day, work up to at least 20 minutes a day - it's great for the bowels, the sunshine will help you produce vitamin D3 which will help with energy levels as well as fighting off stray cancer cells.  The endorphins from walking will help decrease pain and will contribute to a general sense of well-being.  Plus you need the oxygenation to help metabolize away the anesthesia. (Plenty of water is important for detoxification of anesthesia also.) Take care, and if you don't mind, let us know what you find out. Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: 2 things you can do that would be a great help: 1. Help her with physical therapy exercises to regain use of that arm and those chest muscles.  Many women get discouraged because at first those exercises are hard and tedious.  But they are very important.  She should have been given pictures of exercises to do - encourage her to do them, and sit or stand and do them with her (e.g. if she is to be walking her hand up the wall - stand beside her and walk your hand up the wall, too. make it a very gentle competition - only she is competing against herself - not against you.  Put a mark on the wall at the highest point she can reach each day - so she can physically see her progress.) A very good exercise that she may not have been given, is to have someone face her and put their hands out against hers.  Very gently push her hands forward  one at a time, and then  both together.  Have her resist your pushing. This needs to be done VERY gently at first, then strength of your pushing can increase as she tolerates it.  Also, the two of you can put your hands together and raise both arms to the ceiling, pushing gently against each other as you go.  Let her decide when to stop, but encourage her to go as high as she can each time without too much pain.) 2.  Help her have things to laugh and chuckle about.  keeping a sense of humor and laughing (good belly laughs, little chuckles, even tiny little giggles or smiles - ALL will help.)  Laughter releases body chemicals that are wonderful for healing, fighting off infection, and that cancer just plain doesn't like!  Plus laughter helps ease internal tensions and promotes the positive attitudes that are so necessary to beat this disease. It also releases endorphins that will minimize pain. Oh - I would add one other thing - DON'T be afraid to take her good nutritious food - especially stuff that can be refrigerated and heated up later.  Cooking is a major chore after a mastectomy.  As are cleaning house, doing dishes and laundry.  Help with those things if she will let you. Buy her some paper plates and good sturdy paper bowls, some plastic glasses and some plastic silverware, so  she doesn't have to do dishes when no one's there to help. I wish you and her the best! Take good care of yourself, too! Sincerely, Tre

You can try using natural estrogen blockers and aromatase inhibitors - foods, herbs/botanicals, and over-the-counter supplements to treat your cancer.  They do the same things as the Tamoxifen and Arimidex, but are much gentler on the body, and have the benefit of providing other cancer-fighting components as well (antioxidants, proanthocyanidins, etc.)  I was able to lower my estradiol level from above 30 to below 5 with such a regimen, a combination of things such as grape seed extract, green tea, an aspirin a day, garlic, etc. You are welcome to take a look at what I did - I have posted my regimen on my blog.  The article is not intended as a prescription for others - everyone's body chemistry is different, and what works very well for one person may not be as effective for another.  But I am happy to provide information on the kinds of things women can use to block and inhibit estrogen from feeding cancer while providing nutrients that will work to attack and destroy cancer. I've also posted my story on my blog - why I took this route instead of aromasin, etc - if you want to take a look at that also my story http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/08/my-stor my regimen http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/09/my-pers There are six supplements that a lot of leading advocates of natural therapy recommend.  All six in combination are a powerful cancer-fighting too.  For someone who might choose to take only one or two of these, selenium is the most important: selenium:  200 mcg/day (can start with 400mcg/day but only for a few weeks) magnesium:  200 - 250 mg/day (350 mg/day max), take with food zinc:  50 mg/day (can start with 100mg/day but only for a few weeks), take with food manganese: 10 - 15 mg/day, take with food calcium: 1200 mg/day We need Vitamin D-3 to be able to absorb and utilize calcium. Our bodies manufacture D-3 if we get adequate sunlight (15 - 20 minutes exposure/day) - but I do not believe in leaving this to chance, so also recommend a Vitamin D-3 supplement, 1000 - 2000 iu/day (10,000 iu/day max)  Drinking plenty of pure, fresh water is also of vital importance.  We need really good hydration to carry cancer-fighting compounds to the cells, and we need that same hydration to carry toxins and by-products of cancer cell death away.  Green tea is also an excellent detoxifier, as is bentonite clay. Essiac tea is also an excellent detox and anti-cancer choice.  Not as simple as using green tea.  You won't find it in my regimen, but if you do a search on CC for essiac tea, and look at the messages Shemay has posted, you will find the recipe and some great web links for essiac tea. Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: On 7/29/2008 smkline1978 wrote: My mother just had a mam. and they said that there was a shadowed area that was not there last year so she had a altrasound and they said the same thing and yesterday, she just went for a MRI.  SHe has a Aunt (I think) that had breast cancer but that is all that I know.   Should i be worried about this shadowed area? and has anyone ever heard of this? Lots of women have shadows show up on mammogram and ultrasound that are not cancer. The fact that they sent her for an MRI rather than an immediate biopsy indicates they are still unsure what this shadow represents, which overall is a good thing.  It very well could  be something benign. Some women have fatty tumors or other conditions in their breasts that are not cancer and may or may not cause concern.  Sometimes there can be calcifications in the breast that may mimic shadows on mammogram. Sometimes it is just dense breast tissue that isn't well visualized by mammogram or ultrasound - positioning can affect the pictures from year to year, as could certain medical conditions.   Some women have suspicious spots in their breasts that the doctors will watch for another 6 months or year or longer - if they show big changes, the docs recommend biopsy, whereas if they don't change, they may just be considered a benign abnormality.  sometimes these shadows are determined to represent "fibrocystic breast disease,"  (the theory/research/treatment of this is finally changing for the better!!!) And yes, sometimes women do have cancer diagnosed through MRI. But for right now, from what you are saying, that very well might  not be the case for your mom.  waiting for test results is hard, so step back, take a deep breath, and focus on what is rather than what could be.  Personally I think Today always has enough troubles of its own without borrowing from tomorrow. If when you all get the report it's good news, please let us know so we can rejoice with you.  If it's bad news, we're here for you then, too. I hope this helps, at least a little, and my best to you and your mom, Tre

Posts.Content: I agree with Tam43 - 6 months is about the norm for scanning, unless there is a SIGNIFICANT increase in symptoms. Also, especially with mets to the bone, care needs to be taken as to how often she is exposed to the scans.  While CT, PET, MRI do not produce the same amounts of radiation, they still should be minimized for the safety of the patient. In the meantime, there are other tests that can be done to determine the effectiveness of treatment.  If the doctor drew cancer markers (bloodwork that indicates the presence of cancer) on your mother before treatment, he/she could draw them again - a decrease in the value of the markers would indicate effective treatment, although it will not give as much information as a scan. Tell your mom's dr your concerns, ask how soon he will do the next scan, and ask if there are other things that he can do in the meantime to help alleviate your concerns. Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: On 10/2/2008 michele1 wrote: I am new here and at a point where my head is just spinning. I have a Midwife who handles my OB-GYN care.  Lost trust in the doctors where I live and it took my way too long regain trust in the medical field.  Per her request due to a .25 cm lump and some not so good family history I have been through mammogram (both regular and bi-lateral) and ultra sound.  Both showed to be normal, also note I am only 43 years old and have never had children and only weigh in now 102 lbs.  I have lost 6 lbs over the last 2 1/2 months and it wasn't on purpose. She, my doc wanted a biopsy done sends me to a Dr to find out what this mass is.  Dr views my data and checks me and says I want you to come back in 4 months any changes you call me asap.  There is abnormal tissue per him and I'm like okay I guess I wait. Help explain why I am waiting, I am a bundle of nerves, my dentist and hygenist had a stern talking with me about every reason not to wait.  I made an appt with my midwife so we can talk about this.  I was not expecting to walk out of the surgens office with out the biospy being done. Is this normal?  My Aunt was just diagnosed 3 months ago with Ductal Carsamona In Situ stage 0 because of imaging tech.  We live in different cities. Hi Michele. More and more I am hearing women say that their drs want to wait a few months, and then take another look.  Lots of these women aren't happy with that, as neither was I a little less than a year ago when my doc said that to me.  So, you are not alone in being nervous about this.  I want to address several things.  Sounds like you are concerned that this is cancer perhaps because you are losing weight?  I would not think that a lump as small as 0.25cm, even if it is cancer, would be enough to cause 6 pounds weight loss in 2 1/2 months. Might be something else going on there.  Would you be comfortable going to a different type of doc, like and osteopath, or naturopath - if you have availability where you live? They might be able to help you investigate the weight loss seperate of this breast problem.  OK, about the lump.  Yes, there are things other than cancer that this could be.  Sometimes women have lumps that are cyst like in nature - called fibrocystic condition. Most of the time they are benign, but there have been cases where they became cancerous.  Perhaps the surgeon feels that is the case with you - that this is perhaps just fibrocystic but is not sure, and therefore wants to see you again to see if there are changes. I would think, however, that if that were the case, he would have told you that, other than saying this is "abnormal tissue." So, since you know there is a lump, and since the doc says it's abnormal tissue, maybe you should consider getting another opinion.  I certainly would ask the midwife about that, if there is someone else to whom she could give you a referral. If you live anywhere near a teaching hospital/university hospital, you might consider going there, or check around and find out who is the best breast cancer doc in the area, and go to them.  (Yes, I know you are shy of the profession right now, but not ALL physicians are bad guys, and you need an answer about this, if at least for your own peace of mind.) The other thing you might ask about is the possibility of a CT scan or PET scan. Ultrasound imaging can be pretty good, but it's like any other diagnostic tool - can miss things.  The other thing you could do is start now on a preventative, anti-cancer diet and perhaps some supplements. That way if the determination IS to wait, you can be doing something proactive in the meantime, and possibly gain some of your weight back.  Your midwife might well be able to get you started on that track, and there are plenty of resources on the internet. (Most of the links I could give you are for people already diagnosed with cancer. I would have to do some looking to find appropriate resources for prevention - please send me a private reply if you would want some help with diet and supplements.)  You could also take a look at the prevention message board, and at some of the articles on Cancer Compasses homepage.  Even do a search on the site - I know I've seen good articles and messages on it, I just don't have the links to give you right now.  Whatever you do, when your nerves start getting cranked up, if you're getting overwhelmed, just step back from it, take some slow deep breaths, and refocus on whatever your task is at hand.  This is a small lump.  Doesn't mean you shouldn't find out what it is, but it DOES mean that the sky is not going to fall in if it takes you some time to get this issue resolved. Prevention is the absolute best cure, so getting started on a more cancer-preventive pro-active diet, etc, will be a very positive step. If we can't prevent cancer, then early detection is the very next best cure - as I'm sure you've heard over and over, the earlier cancer is found, the easier it is to treat.  That is true - but remember, this is a quite small lump - not going to be a disaster if it takes a few weeks or even a month to get a definitive answer. Use the time wisely to learn about foods and exercise and detoxification - stuff that keeps the body healthy and fights off cancer cells. And regardless of what happens, start drinking plenty of pure fresh water. Is one of the very healthiest things you can do for yourself.  I hope this helps, and I wish you the very best, including speedy answers to your situation. Sincerely, Tre
Posts.Title: My head is spinning

Posts.Content: On 11/18/2008 pret13 wrote: I am very confused.  I am reading from this cite that fructose in fruit juice is not good for any one who has gone through cancer.  I have been drinking a LOT of Lipton Green Tea (has antioxidants) because I love it. I just looked at the label and it said high fructose level. Now I am scared.  Also, should people who have gone through cancer stay away from sugar altogther?  No cake or ice cream,  even once in a while?  Lastly, my nutritionist said to stay away from soybeans and flaxseed.  On this site I am reading that it is GOOD. Is there an expert out there that can advise me on these questions?    Yes, these ARE confusing issues. I've done a LOT of research on natural treatment for cancer, so I think I can answer a few of your questions.  Most simple sugars are NOT a good choice for cancer.  Cancer cells require a LOT of energy, and they like to get it from sugar. Glucose, sucrose, lactose, dextrose - not good choices.  However, fructose is actually a GOOD sugar choice, in that fructose inhibits glycolysis (fermentation of sugar), which is the means by which cancer cells  get their energy. Doesn't mean you can go overboard on fructose, but raw fruits and veggies that contain fructose are ok, as is small amounts of crystallized fructose.  As for fruit juice - don't add any sugar.  Now, about the green tea.  Buy either green tea bags, or loose leaf green tea, and brew your own. Use the purest water you can get - either steam-distilled or filtered thru reverse osmosis is best.  Then if you need a sweetener, either use small amounts of crystallized fructose or 100% pure organic honey. (100% pure maple syrup is also OK as a sweetener , but I don't think it would taste very good with green tea.) Don't depend on the sweeteners in store-bought green tea - if it says high fructose level, chances are that it has been made with high fructose corn syrup, which is an absolute no-no.  (One among many reasons why soda pop is also a no-no.) (Fructose, and high fructose corn syrup are NOT the same thing. If you're going to buy a sweetener, get 100% pure organic crystallized fructose - available at health food stores and online.  AVOID high fructose corn syrup.) As for deserts, unless you know that they are made of just the natural fruit, and only fructose as sweetener, stay away from them. A small bit of cake or ice cream for a special occaision is ok - everybody needs to celebrate, and enjoy a holiday etc, but this really needs to be limited to a small portion only on that special day.  STEVIA is an herb that is an excellent sweetener, and offers no risk as concerns cancer.  just be careful - it is much more sweet than sugar - a tiny little bit goes a very long way. About soybean and flaxseed: both contain phytochemicals called phytoestrogen. (plant estrogen)  For those who have an estrogen receptor positive (or progestin receptor positive) cancer, there is some concern that they can feed the cancer instead of fighting it.  Many researchers are coming to the conclusion that natural foods and herbs that contain very strong phytoestrogens will feed cancer, while those containing weak phytoestrogens will act as estrogen blockers (the same mechanism as tamoxifen.)  Some researchers say that soy inhibits breast cancer. some say that it promotes breast cancer, and some say that it has no effect either way. So the jury's still out on this.  Soy contains genistein and isoflavones; there are attempts to differentiate between the effect of genistein and that of isoflavones - those results just aren't in yet, either.  So, as to whether soy is beneficial or harmful - you're probably going to continue to hear all kinds of different things, because there just isn't overall conclusive evidence that the medical and natural communities are both willing to accept. Personally, I take a practical approach to the question of soy.  For years, soy - especially soy milk, tofu, soybeans - have been recommended as a natural hormone replacement treatment for menopause, and many thousands of women have had success in relieving hot flashes, etc, caused by menopause.  If soy it this effective as a hormone replacer - I question the advisability of depending on it as a hormone blocker, so I recommend that women avoid soy and choose less questionable naturals for this purpose.  Flaxseed is a little different.  Yes, it contains phytoestrogens, too, and it very definitely is a cancer fighter due to some other phytochemicals it contains. Very small amounts of ground flaxseed may possibly act as estrogen blockers. Howeverm, large amounts of flaxseed or concentrated flax oil can actually serve as hormone replacers (a friend of mine who is several years post-menopausal and who is very slender and muscular - doesn't have much fat to produce estrogen - started taking flax oil in yogurt to alleviate some of the sypmptoms of low estrogen levels. This was so successful that she actually started having periods again - when she stopped the flax oil - the periods went away.)  SO - a tsp or less of ground flaxseed/day might be ok, but I wouldn't recommend even that much flaxoil per day, as the phytoestrogens in it are much more concentrated.  And if you do use flax to fight cancer, the lignins in the hulls of the seed are one of the primary cancer fighters, so using ground flax seed is a better choice in  that respect, also. Many women with breast cancer use the Budwig diet - flax oil and cottage cheese - and say it has helped fight the breast cancer. Johanna Budwig theorized that when flaxoil binds to cottage cheese it actually forms a new compound with new properties that you don't get from either alone. She may very well have been right - but personally, I am not willing to take the chance that the strong phytoestrogens in the flax oil are going to feed rather than fight my cancer, so I use only 1/4 tsp ground flax seed in 1/4 - 1/2 cup cottage cheese every day, and otherwise avoid flax in any form for ingestion.) (I do, however, use very tiny amounts of flax oil mixed with vaseline to locally treat vaginal dryness/atrophy caused by the estrogen depletion after hysterectomy and removal of ovaries combined with the anti-estrogen natural therapy I use to keep cancer in remission. Just that tiny amount replenishes those tissues very well - proof enough for me that flax oil contains powerful enough phytoestrogens to act as a hormone replacer rather than blocker.) If your nutritionist is advising you avoid flax and soy, I would say to follow her recommendations. There are plenty of other things you can do naturally to fight or prevent cancer.  Take a look at my blog for some examples: http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/09/my-pers FOr more information on fructose and other natural cancer fighters, take a look at this page from the AP John Cancer Institute - scroll down to the Integrative Therapy section, phase 2 and 3.  I am not recommending the total diet, but rather the specific foods that are explained as cancer fighters. http://www.apjohncancerinstitute.org/cancer/breast-c.htm Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: Hi Jacqueline, You can take some extra-strength tylenol about 30 minutes before the biopsy - that will help.  You might also ask if the Dr will give you a prescription for several valium - you could take a dose the night before, and then one at the same time as the tylenol right before the biopsy. Also, ask if they will be using local anesthesia - that will help too. Practice imaging something pleasant in your mind, such as a warm and peaceful place (like a tropical beach with soothing waves splashing on shore) - then when you have your biopsy, send your mind to that place rather than focusing on what they are doing to your body. Tre

Posts.Content: Hi KellyAnn, I recommend that you support your immune system during treatment with as nutrient rich a diet as you can,  plus some very specific supplements.  Eat as much fresh raw fruits and vegetables as possible (organic, if you can get it - if not, wash them thoroughly with  soap and warm water, and rinse, rinse, rinse.)  You need to be very careful about sugar intake - do not add cane sugar to anything.  It's ok to use crystallized fructose (a cancer fighter, and you can get it at health food stores,) a little bit of pure honey or pure maple syrup, or stevia  (get powdered stevia, NOT stevia extract as it has a lot of alcohol in it.) A lot of people say you can't eat fruit because of the sugar - but actually the fructose in the fruit really does work to fight cancer by inhibiting fermentation,which is how cancer cells get their energy.  Apples are a good cancer fighter - but limit to one a day.  Bananas are a no-no - they are very high in sugar that feeds cancer. (There are lots of other fruits and veggies that are potassium rich - so bananas aren't needed for that.) Any kind of citrus fruit except grapefruit is ok.  Any kind of berry is a good choice - they have many phytochemicals that fight cancer. I recommend people with breast cancer stay away from pomegranate, but cranberries are a really good choice. Grapes - red, black or purple grapes - with the seeds if you can get them, are an excellent cancer fighter.   Cruciferous veggies are key in diet - spinach, kale, cauliflower, broccoli, brussel sprouts, asparagus, beets, cabbage. Limit carrots - they have a very high sugar content that is easily utilized by cancer. (The exception is if you go on a carrot diet - in which case you use the carrot sugar to carry phytochemicals to the cancer cells - but for regular diet choices, limit the carrots.)  Legumes and whole grains will provide not only roughage but also energy and many cancer-fighting phytochemicals.  Corn has a bad rep among a lot of advocates of alternatives, but even corn can be added to the diet for energy and to help keep the bowel regular if constipation becomes a problem during chemo.  Olives and olive oil provide essential fatty acids, plus a lot of OPC's that fight cancer. Eat vinegary foods - the acetic acid in the vinegar fights cancer.  Add a dribble of apple cider vinegar over vegetables once a day, or swallow a tsp of apple cider vinegar in 4 - 5 ounces of warm water, or take an apple cider vinegar supplement.  Flax seed is also an excellent source of essential fatty acids and cancer-fighting phytochemicals.  A lot of people use flax seed oil - but with breast cancer you've got to be careful how much you get, so I recommend 1 - 2 tsp ground brown flax seed a day, maximum - you can mix it in with 1/2 - 3/4 cup cottage cheese or in yogurt, or apple sauce (that would be your apple for the day.)  I add black currants or raisins and roasted pumpkin seeds, plus salt and pepper to taste - makes a good breakfast when combined with a handful of red or black or purple grapes (with the seeds if you can get them) and a big cup of green and/or black tea.  You really need to emphasize B vitamins, both for the lyme disease and the FMS.  I recommend taking a B complex supplement, in addition to trying to eat as vitamin B rich foods as possible. Try to get a supplement with the most variety of the B's and as high a dose as you can.  This is a good example - you can look at this product label for comparison:  http://www.swansonvitamins.com/SWC036/ItemDetail?n=429496718 THere are also 5 minerals that many of the leading experts on alternative treatment for cancer recommend that EVERYONE take, whether they are fighting active cancer or trying to prevent recurrence: selenium:  200 mcg/day (can start with 400mcg/day but only for a few weeks) magnesium:  200 - 250 mg/day (350 mg/day max), take with food zinc:  50 mg/day (can start with 100mg/day but only for a few weeks), take with food manganese: 10 - 15 mg/day, take with food calcium: 1200 mg/day We need Vitamin D-3 to be able to absorb and utilize calcium. Our bodies manufacture D-3 if we get adequate sunlight (15 - 20 minutes exposure/day) - but I do not believe in leaving this to chance, so also recommend a Vitamin D-3 supplement, 1000 - 2000 iu/day (10,000 iu/day max)  You probably would benefit from a good vitamin C supplement, also. That, plus vitamins A and E. Get these supplements seperately - you need above and beyond what you will get in a multiple vitamin preparation. Check with your oncologist - ask if there are specific foods you shouldn't be eating, or supplements you shouldn't be taking, if they will interfere with the chemo.  Also, ask about how much tea it's ok for you to drink - I'm assuming you will be on a blood thinner for your port - drinking large quantities of tea can prolong bleeding time.  Some docs think it's a potential problem, some docs say drink as much as you want.  I would recommend that if you can find a practicing naturopath in your area, go for a consult - get some professional advise specific to YOUR needs as to diet, herbs, and supplementation.  Get online and read about using nutrition to fight cancer. (Don't just get educated about how bad CANCER is - also get educated about how GOOD food and mother nature is.) You are also welcome to take a look at my blog for examples of things you can do to supplement the chemo and fight the cancer naturally:  http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/09/my-pers -anti-cancer-and-health.html  Regardless of what you do, you will need to try to drink plenty of pure fresh water, every day ( a minimum of 64 ounces.)  Detoxification of chemo is absolutely essential to keeping yourself as healthy as possible, and you can't do that without good hydration.  Steam distilled or reverse osmosis filtered water are best, as they eliminate micro-toxins that can be found in even the priciest of bottled waters.  I got one of these distillers - my partner and I use it for all our drinking and cooking water:  http://www.a1-water-distiller.com/ Other foods that are especially good in dealing with both FMS and cancer are garlic and onions. Use as much of them as you can tolerate - either fresh or powdered or minced or whatever form you want.  Other spices that will help are ginger, turmeric, cumin and red pepper (cayenne pepper.)  A lot of people getting chemo can't tolerate spicy food - that may be a problem for you. Some people find that while they can't stand spices, they can eat bitter or sour.  Purple grape juice, dill pickle juice, and very small amounts of pickled ginger root can be  life-savers for the person who has little appetite due to chemo. These are excellent web sites for ideas on diet and supplementation to serve as adjuncts to chemo:  http://www.cancertutor.com http://www.lefcancer.org http://alkalizeforhealth.net http://alternativecancer.us I wish you the best.  Hang in there - it seems really scary right now, but you will get through it the same as everyone else, one day at a time, or even when you have to, one moment at at time.  If you get overwhelmed, make yourself take a step back, take some long slow deep breaths, and re-focus on whatever it is you need to be doing at that moment, right then. We can only ever definitely affect the moment we are in right now - so concentrate on doing that, and in that way the future will take care of itself. Please let us know how you are doing from time to time.  Lots of good people here who care about your well-being. Sincerely, Tre
Posts.Title: IBC: Found out I have it...need advise please!

Posts.Content: On 9/24/2008 Partner wrote: Hi My beautiful wife (lucy) and the mother of my 3 amazing children (girls aged 6, 8 and 9) had a bi-lateral mastectomy and lymphectomy two weeks ago and starts chemotherapy next week. Things are tough - particularly explaining things to the kids - but we are handling it as best we can. I have a question - the biopsy from surgery showed a grade III cancer on the left and a grade I on the right. The CT scan and the lymph results came back all clear (first bit of good news Lucy has had since this began). Does the fact that the cancer occured in both breasts mean that it is in fact metastatic, despite the CT and lymph results, or is the occurunce of cancer in both breasts considered a 'localised' event? The oncologist did try to explain this but it sometimes hard to take it all in at the time. Hi Partner, Yes, understanding all this medical talk can be very difficult, especially when you're first hearing it all. I think that perhaps you are not understanding the difference between stage of cancer and grade of cancer - many people use those terms interchangeably, but they are not at all the same thing.  Stage of cancer indicates location and involvement of tissues. Metastasis is indicated by stage rather than grade. With the CT and lymph results coming back clear, that means there is no metastasis. I am guessing that these 2 tumors are both classified as Stage I, but you should ask the dr to make sure. This is a good reference article on staging: http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/diagnosis/staging.jsp Grade of cancer means how aggressive the cancer is (how fast it grows, and how likely it is to invade other tissues.) The lower the grade number, the less aggressive and invasive it is.   If one was a spread of the other, they would both share the same characteristics and therefore both be the same grade. The fact that the cancer on the left is Grade III and the cancer on the right is Grade I indicates that this is 2 seperate cancers that have occurred at the same time.  (Sounds kind of hard to believe, but this actually does happen to women more than once every blue moon.) Unfortunately, I was not able to find a really good article that talks about grade in laymen's terms, but you might take a look at this reference: http://www.cancerbackup.org.uk/Cancertype/Breast/Causesdiagn So if I am understanding the information you gave correctly, then yes, your wife's cancer would be classified as localised. But it is not just one incident of localised cancer - it is  2 incidents of localised cancer, because it is indeed 2 different occurences of cancer. When you talk to the dr again, he/she may well tell you they are not only 2 different instances of cancer, but that they are two different types of breast cancer. Having 2 different types of cancer at the same time could complicate things somewhat.  One may require one type of chemo, while the other requires a different type of chemo.  Hopefully that will NOT be the case, and that both can be treated well with the same drugs - will make it a little easier for your wife.  As for your kids, don't try to get too technical with them.  Lots of times they require answers that are much simpler than we  imagine, and lots of times these wonderful little people are capable of understanding much more than we expect!  And your daughters are at just the age when it's fun to learn how to cook and do things like mommy (as long as they are still given plenty of time to play), so things like encouraging them to all  chip in and help you get supper put on the table because mommy's medicine makes her really tired could very well turn out to be a great adventure for them!  I hope my explanation helps - at least maybe it will give you more questions to ask the dr!  I recommend your wife take a little notebook and a pen with her to treatments and appts, so she can write stuff down to keep track - chemo can sometimes be very immediately tiring. Always good to have notes for reference later! Wishing you, Lucy and the girls the best, Tre
Posts.Title: Metastatic or not?

Posts.Content: I think many, if not most, people are turned upside down when they learn of cancer, have to deal with unexpected surgery, then try to get started on subsequent treatment. And it's worse when it's stuff you don't know anything about.  I worked as an RN for many years so was quite familiar with the terminology, but I still found I had a LOT of questions and things I didn't understand after my dr's visits.  I learned to take a small notebook and pen with me anywhere I went.  I would write down my questions and concerns beforehand, and would make sure I had covered every one of them , and gotten satisfactory answers before I left whomever I was seeing. (The docs got so they expected that from me, and it worked well.)  I also made sure to write down their answers - the docs got so they automatically printed out reports for me also - that worked very well, meant I didn't have to copy down all the technical stuff, yet I had it available for reference when I got home and had time to sit and absorb information and formulate new questions or a plan of action.  Plus there's the fact that not every dr or medical person does a good job of explaining stuff.  My surgeon for my breast cancer is one of the best in the nation - he's a brilliant man and truly expert at what he does, but his bedside manner leaves a little to be desired.  I really had to stop him and tell him that even tho I had been a nurse, I still wasn't understanding what he was saying, and I needed him to talk to me in everyday language. I think he was a little perturbed at that, but once he realized that I really wanted to know and that I intended to be a very active participant in my own care, he came around and communication got much better.  And sometimes that's what ya gotta do, say "hey look Doc, I don't understand what you're saying, but I want to understand it, so help me out." And then persist until whomever starts giving you the answers you need. Please feel free to send me a private message if you think I could be of further assistance as you and your wife and family move through this process.   And please make sure to take good care of yourself, too. Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: I don't have any answers for you, but did want to ask:  did they do a thorough eye exam on you, checking for macular degeneration? While yes, drusen can occur with some chemotherapies, it can also be a significant symptom of developing macular degeneration. While not as immediately threatening as the risk of a detached retina, it still is a debilitating eye condition that can be treated to some extent if detected early enough.  If you haven't had a very thorough eye exam since the development of these drusen, perhaps you should make an appt with a good opthamalogist. I wish you the very best. Tre

Posts.Content: Mistakes do happen, but this certainly sounds fishy to me.  Did they biopsy this cyst in June, or did they just say wait to see if it grows bigger and if it does we'll remove it?  Did you have a mammogram done then?  What other test did you have?  If they didn't think necessary to biopsy it, did they give you a reason why? Sounds like someone really dropped the ball as concerns your case - even if they really and truly did think it was just a benign cyst, they still should have taken precautions to make sure, instead of letting it go until it got bigger. You might want to be talking to a lawyer about this, see if you have any legal recourse as concerns upcoming medical bills, care, etc.  At the very least, please write down everything you remember about what happened - dates, times, places, names.  What you were told and by whom. Put this in a file with any copies of medical tests, whatever you may have.  I would also try to get copies of stuff that was done, if you don't have those copies.  I would also consider getting a second opinion on medical treatment from this point forward.  If whomever didn't think that the cyst was anything worth investigating until it'd had time to grow, were it me,  I would be questioning their ability to treat this thing now.  And it sounds like your faith in them might have taken a big hit - that's really important too.  Need to have faith in the people treating you - staying with a dr with whom you are angry is not always a good idea. I hope things start going better for you.  Please keep in touch - let us know how you are doing.   Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: Hey Shirley, When I started to put together my own herbal/natural regimen to fight mets, I also read some very convincing data on the effectiveness of iodine in killing cancer.  I had already started taking a kelp supplement for thyroid health, so I doubled the supplement as part of my cancer regimen.  I would caution that people with mets to organs such as the liver and kidneys, adrenal and other endocrine glands might need to use caution in iodine therapy.  It takes a lot of iodine to become overloaded, but it can happen, and those whose metabolism and detoxification abilities have been compromised would possibly be at greater risk.  For that reason anyone who might consider iodine therapy should do so with their physician's approval, so the appropriate tests can be done to monitor for safe serum iodine levels. Posts.Content: Hey Noahgail, I hope you've read my response to your other message. Unless the drs think that your cancer is just so invasive and threatening that you have to start chemo immediately, I would imagine that you will have at least a few weeks time to recover from surgery before starting chemo. Many docs want their patients to be about a month post-op before they start chemo, so that incisions and underlying tissue have a chance to heal quite a bit before being put to the onslaught of chemo.  Much less risk of complications that way. Plus it gives a woman time to start to recover from anesthesia, and to start to get her head around an altered body image - those things are all important.  So, if you have a chance to talk to the doc before your surgery Tuesday, I certainly would ask just how soon they are anticipating you will be starting the chemo.  You may have more time to prepare than it seems like right now.  And if the doc says the chemo will be started immediately or within a few days or a week or two after the surgery, I think I'd be asking for just flat out answers about how aggressive and advanced they think this cancer is.  Might not be questions you want to ask, but right now you are your own best advocate - women do themselves a great favor to adopt that approach.  As for waking up from anesthesia and moving on, it is just that.  Everybody reacts a little bit differently to the drugs, but most anesthesiologists these days are giving drugs that have an amnesiac effect, so that people don't remember a lot of what happened when they went back into the OR and when they were in the recovery room.  That's a pretty good thing.  I was given one of those type of drugs when I had surgery on my hand a number of years ago - every surgery since then I've made sure to remind the anesthesiologist to give me that type of drug, and they're happy to oblige. If you have an overnight hospital stay (or several days) - make sure to be getting up and moving around just as soon as you're allowed.  The more you walk, the more you deep breath and cough to get you lungs working again, the better you will be.  Once you get home, you've got to start doing gentle exercises to get your arm and shoulder loosened up and moving and to get those muscles limber and reduce swelling.  The dr or the staff at the hospital should be giving you a pamphlet that shows the type exercises you should do - if not, you can find them online ( do a web search for postoperative mastectomy exercises.)  You might even practice a few of them this weekend - things like walking your fingers up a wall, or holding your hand in front of your breast and very gently pushing forward as if there was slight resistance. And try to find some time to do SOMETHING fun in the next day or two.  Laughter is very important for the next few days and the weeks to come. Gather as much of it as you can! Keeping you in my thoughts, Tre
Posts.Title: I'm having mastectomy tuesday

Posts.Content: On 7/31/2008 brawleymom wrote: I am almost a year out from my mastectomy but am still doing reconstruction. I have a gel implant and last week had a dog ear removed. Nipple comes next. Throughout my entire cancer journey, my rib cage has been tender, but more so lately.  Is this possible still a year later?  My bra hurts it, and every once in awhile I will get those throbbing pain under the rib cage but most of the time it just aches. It even looks like it sticks out more on that side. Of course I am terrified of bone mets or even liver mets and will ask my onco when I go next month, but my husband keeps reminding me that this has bothered me the whole time--I just think it is worse now.  Some people have said rib cage pain is common--just wondering if it would continue even a year later?  Ache is not bad enough to take anything...maybe an Ibuprofen or something. Also, it does not seem to hurt as much when i get up. Any advice to help my sanity would be great. By the way, I did not have chemo or radiation, nor do i take any pills. Cancer was a wierd one, with a 6 cm tumor. Surgeon told me she was very aggressive in getting all the tissue out. your help is appreciated!   Molly   Hi Molly, Yes, rib cage pain is common - but it doesn't have to be permanent. It's possible they nicked your rib when they did your mastectomy. That could cause pain for quite a while, but should eventually subside. I think it's more likely that you have a problem with lymphedema in your chest wall and/or scarring.   This is a pretty good picture of a normal breast: http://www.drsusanloveresearchfoundation.org /breast_diagram.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.drsusanloveresearchfoundation.org /breast_diagram. You can see that connective tissue surrounds all of the actual mammary glands and all the connective tissue is surrounded by fat. This area is also rich with lymphatics (not shown.)  When the breast is removed, especially if there is going to be an inplant, the surgeon tries to take out all the tissue affected by the tumor while leaving as much of the connective tissue and fat as possible, because it is these tissues that will help hold the implant in place.  That means that these tissues become much more susceptible to fluid retention and scarring than they were before the surgery. I've got some links and references that I sent to another lady who was also having this type pain.  I think she found some things there that helped her. You might look particularly at the material about bras interfering with circulation and lymph drainage, and at the article about using a rebounder (mini-trampoline) for exercise to promote drainage and break up scarring. A really good way to tell if your bra is contributing to the problem is to try going without it for a week.  (This is what a female oncologist suggested to me when I was having problems with drainage and scarring - I've now been without the bra for 5 1/2 months!)  If the pain goes away, or decreases significantly, you have at least part of your answer. The "Dr Susan Love Breast Book, 4th ed"  is excellent.  I got it for $22 - well worth every penny to get the most up-to-date  info from this lady.  Also, I think at least one of these links talks about "Phantom" pain - I don't include it to make light of your pain, but rather to contrast with the articles that  illuminate a real cause for pain.  Post mastectomy pain is real, and it is treatable,  but not a whole lot of docs have caught onto the fact that it does exist, it DOES have a cause, and shouldn't be ignored. I hope this helps.  Please feel free to send me a message if you have more questions. Tre "Dr Susan Love's Breast Book" by Susan M. Posts.Content: The weight gain is probably not technically a side effect of the drugs, but the treatment may be responsible.  Hormone receptor drugs cause an estrogen-depleted state.  Our bodies need estrogen to survive - not just for reproductive purposes, but for healthy skin, bones, and other processes.  When our endocrine system perceives that there is not enough estrogen, it tries to find a work-around.  One of the ways our bodies make estrogen is through fat cells - the more fat we have, the more estradiol we will produce. Therefore, if your system was trying to produce more estradiol to make up for estrogen loss otherwise, your metabolism may have been slowed and other processes changed so as to cause weight gain. Many women find that they gain a lot of weight after a hysterectomy.  For many years drs have poo-pooed this as just an emotional reaction and dysfunctional coping after surgery.  Thank goodness there are now medical professionals who are beginning to realize and accept that there is a very real physiologic reason for this weight gain, and are attempting to help women cope with estrogen depletion through natural therapies.  15 pounds over 4 months is distressing;  the average over a period of several years seems to be about 50 pounds. So, in one way, your weight gain could be seen as an encouraging thing - if your body is perceiving itself to be in an estrogen depleted state, then the hormone receptor therapy is very effective at depriving any cancer cells in your body of estrogen.  As for reining in the weight gain, the thing that would help most - supplementing with natural phytoestrogens - is the one thing you shouldn't do, because it negates the hormone receptor therapy.  If the weight gain is the major thing that is bothering you, and you are otherwise doing well on treatment, then I recommend you step up some other things to keep your weight where it is now and not gain anymore.  Drink lots and lots of pure, fresh water (steam-distilled or reverse-osmosis-filtered are best.)  This will help regulate your metabolism.  Add exercise to your routine - at least 20 minutes 3 - 4 times a week of an aerobic exercise.  Walking or swimming are fine choices. Use detoxifiers, like green or black tea - they help eliminate toxins in the blood stream that can contribute to a sluggish metabolism. Increase your intake of antioxidants - a supplement called SOD (superoxide dismutase) is an excellent choice for that.  Make sure you are getting plenty of B vitamins, especially vitamin B12. Watch your dietary intake of processed foods.  A diet based on raw, fresh produce (organic when possible) is best.  Animal foods slow down the digestive tract, and contribute to weight gain.  Unless you are already vegetarian or vegan, best to limit to 3 -4 ounces of meat, poultry or fish 3 -4 times a week.  Raw milk is best; if you can't get it or don't like it, try to get milk from grass-fed dairy cows that aren't given any growth hormones.  The same with butter and cheese.  Eggs should be from free range chickens that aren't given hormones or antibiotics.   For sweetener use stevia, crystallized fructose, or small amounts of 100%pure honey or 100% maple syrup.   Make sure to get a good intake of essential fatty acids - they play a very important role in both metabolism, the immune system, the endocrine system, and fighting cancer.  (A handful of roasted pumpkin seeds will give you all the omegas you need for one day, plus lots of good vegetable protein. recipe: http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/09/roasted )  Last, but by no means least, cut out all partially-hydrogenated or fully-hydrogenated fats from your diet. Our bodies cannot digest/metabolise these, but rather than eliminating them, they are stored as fat, because the body has hope that maybe some other day they can be accessed for energy and digested/metabolised then. Just doesn't ever happen - everything we eat in the way of hydrogenized fats follows the old rule: "once across the lips, always on the hips."  The best oils to use are cold-pressed or expeller pressed organic olive oil, or expeller pressed 100% pure coconut oil from fresh coconuts as opposed to dried chopra.  Both olive oil and coconut oil promote metabolism while providing wonderful cancer-fighting nutrients to the body. I wish you great success in your treatment, and a wonderful holiday! Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: If you don't want to go with a prescription vaginal estrogen supplement, you can make your own ointment that will work just as well and will cost much less. Get some food grade organic flax seed oil (with lignins, if you can find it) and some good quality petroleum jelly (vaseline).  Mix 1/2 tsp flax oil with 1 TBSP vaseline in a container with a tight sealing lid. No applicator needed,  Just use clean hands, put a small amount on your fingertips, and apply this ointment around the urethra and in the vagina. Do this at least once daily for the first 7 - 10 days, then thereafter as needed. My dr approves of this self-treatment, and my research has revealed no contra-indications.  Not nearly enough phytoestrogen in this little bit of flax oil to cause problems with cancer, and many naturopathic specialists are recommending flax oil even in the treatment of estrogen-positive breast cancer.   And the best part - it really works well, and is very inexpensive. I use Barleans flax oil -  organic and high quality - I get it at the local health food store.  It needs to be refrigerated or it will go rancid - don't buy it from a seller who doesn't refrigerate it.  Make sure to shake it up well before measuring your 1/2 tsp out.  You DO NOT need to refrigerate the ointment after you make it, as long as you keep it in a clean, tightly sealed container away from heat and light.  (I recommend you don't refrigerate - I tried that - it just got very runny and didn't work as well.)  Make sure to always use clean hands when mixing and applying, so that you don't contaminate the remaining ointment. If you still have any of your batch left after 10 - 12 days,  discard it, clean the container with hot soapy water and rinse well, and make a new batch.(Always clean the container well before making a new batch.) I recommend that you still use a lubricant for intimacy - menopausal tissue (chemically induced or not) - just doesn't lubricate as well as it used to, regardless of how well replenished it is. Also, if you are using prophylactics for birth control , probably best to allow time for the ointment to fully absorb before intimacy, because vaseline can weaken latex.  If you are interested in complementary therapy to lessen the other side effects of the femara, let me know, and I'll send you some references. Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: The anti-estrogen drugs (and I do mean ALL of them, from tamoxifen to arimidex to aromasin to faslodex to femara, etc) are an especially nasty thing the pharmaceutical industry has inflicted on women.  I am sure that had these drugs been targeted at men, once the side effects became known, they never would have made it through research and development. Whether they be estrogen-receptor blockers, or an aromatase inhibitors, these drugs for some women induce an extremely severe chemical menopause. Unfortunately, the one thing that would best help overcome the drastic side effects - administration of estrogen - is the one thing that these women can't have, if they don't want to risk recurring cancer. The drastic side effects CAN be reversed, over time, and women can naturally maintain low estrogen levels - it takes time, patience, and perseverance to get and stay there.  Be especially careful to avoid supplements/herbs/botanicals that are recommended for treatment of menopause, as they contain very strong phytoestrogens that will act as estrogen replacers, and while rapidly easing off joint and bone pain, will also raise risk of recurring cancer. Diet has to be the main component in regaining the ground lost after months or years of treatment with these drugs. Fortunately, the things that women most need to eat to recover are also the very things that will work against allowing recurrence of cancer. Push as much raw fruits and vegetables, organic whole foods as you absolutely can (except bananas, grapefruit, pomegranates, carrots and soy.)  Limit red meat - indeed limit all meat - two or three 3 or 4 ounce servings of meat a week is plenty.  The by-products of meat breakdown and metabolism for many women will only complicate detoxification of these drugs from the body and the rebuilding of connective and nerve tissue and bone. Eat a lot of garlic and onions - they are extremely detoxifying and healing. Use cayenne pepper to improve circulation. Eat vinegary (pickled) foods - they provide a lot of micronutrients. Olives and olive oil are important foods, along with spinach and kale, beets, cranberries and other berries, cruciferous veggies.  Potatoes are a good choice - but not sweet potatoes or yams - they are very high in phytoestrogens.  Supplementation is a great idea. All of the B vitamins plus choline are absolutely essential for recovery.  A good vitamin C.  Calcium, magnesium, zinc, selenium, manganese and vitamin D3.  Vitamins A and E.  More than you will get in a one-a-day multiple vitamin.   Drink as much fresh pure water as possible - you need it for detoxification, and for building new healthy and strong tissues.  Steam distilled or reverse osmosis purified water are the best.  Drink plenty of green and/or black teas - they are powerful detoxifiers and contain lots of anti-oxidants/cancer-fighters. A simple regular strength (325 mg) generic aspirin a day will help relieve inflammation, and will also inhibit prostaglandins necessary to produce estrogen.  Grape seed extract and essential fatty acids (the omega's - gamma linolenic acid and conjugated linoleic acid) are vitally important for recovery.  You can get the fatty acids through several different types of oil or through roasted pumpkin or squash seeds - just be careful with flax seed oil - it contains very strong phytoestrogens that might act as estrogen replacers instead of blockers.   Much better to use a maxiumum of a tsp or two of ground flax seeds in cottage cheese or yogurt or applesauce a day. (A tiny bit of food grade flax oil applied periodically on the nether area to offset dryness of very delicate tissues will not pose a problem as far as too much estrogen.) Avoid evening primrose oil (unless you are HER2 positive - studies have shown definite benefit there), black and blue cohosh, red clover flowers and any kind of soy.  To get an idea of the kinds of things that women can do to start their bodies healing while also continuing to work to either fight or prevent cancer, take a look at the regimen I used:  http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/09/my-pers It's not intended as a prescription for all people - but certainly can give women good ideas of a place to start.  There are lots of other good articles on my blog - about the different types of vitamin B, about vitamin C, some recipes, etc.  Feel free to look at whatever interests you. My best recommendation for any woman trying to recover from a prescritption anti-estrogen therapy is to find a naturopathic practitioner, and get them to work with you on the foods, supplements, herbs that you each need to best fuel your body for recovery while working to keep estrogen levels down gently and naturally.  Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: Taxol is a relatively mild chemotherapeutic drug, but for some people it can really cause some nasty chest pain.  I had 4 doses - one a month - with my third dose my chest over my heart hurt bad enough they put me in the hospital on oxygen and for diagnostic testing and observation over night. (Arterial blood gases at intervals throughout the night was NOT fun!)  My tests showed everything was normal - heart and lungs were in great shape.  They theorized that the Taxol was  irritating the tissues in my chest wall and causing the pain.  Treatment? - Tylenol and rest. I did also have some shortness of breath during the time I was on chemo (and for another month or so thereafter), but as my they monitored my oxygen levels during treatments and on follow up visits and it was always ok, I attributed the shortness of breath to poor quality of sleep and the stress on my body/blood cells from the chemo in general. PLus the bodily stresses of recovering from surgeries, trying to metabolize anesthesia from my system. (Metabolic by-products of anesthesia can take 6 - 8 months or longer to totally clear the body.)  I tried to make sure to eat foods that boosted the immune system and provide building blocks for new blood cells, and if I was tired, I rested - even if that meant I couldn't get other things done. Having a window open and a fan blowing for a fresh source of air helped, plus sleeping with my head and chest elevated. (Yes, it's winter now - but if you can crack a window even a little, the cold air may help, as it actually contains more oxygen than warm or hot air.) Has she reported these symptoms to the oncologist, and what was his response?  At the least I would think her bloodwork should be checked - make sure she isn't getting anemic. Pulse oximetry can be done right there in the dr's office if they have the equipment - that would show if her oxygen saturation is ok. They might want to do an EKG - see if there is a heart abnormality, as chemotherapy does have the potential to do harm. The other thing that can be a problem with chemo, causing shortness of breath, is lack of proper nutrition. The chemo gave me pervasive nausea low-grade nausea/queasiness.  I didn't vomit, but boy, my stomach just couldn't settle, food didn't taste good,  and I sure didn't feel like eating. Really hard to get the nutrient basics that way.  I found myself taking the antiemetic round the clock for at least 5 or 6 days after each chemo - just to minimize the nausea.  If the dr doesn't have any objection, your wife might consider taking some vitamin supplements, especially the B vitamins, vitamin C and vitamin D3, if she is able to tolerate them with food. I have some articles about vitamin C and the B vitamins on my blog - you are welcome to look at them.  They list good food sources for these - she should eat as much of them as she can tolerate unless the doc says otherwise.   Unsweetened concord grape juice - very cold - is a good addition to meals and snacks, as it's very nutritious, and it masks the "bad" flavor of foods caused by the chemo.   Really helped me be able to eat the stuff I knew I needed.  I also found that I did better with sour or bitter foods, rather than sweet or spicy, or even bland.  I ate more saurkraut and Klaussen dill pickles, and drank more grape juice when I was on chemo than I had previously eaten  in the whole rest of my life combined - but that was ok because they are all nutritious and contain cancer-fighting nutrients! Here's the web address for the first of my articles on vitamin B (there are 10  posts on vitamin b, plus the one on vitamin c - you can use the search box to find the rest): http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/09/buzz-on I wish you both the best in getting through this.  Keep your chins up - it may seem unending now, but take it one day at a time until you get to brighter days ahead. Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: On 12/19/2008 will be ok2 wrote: I am a 35 year old who just had a double mastectomy with immediate reconstruction.  I have also completed half of my "dose dense" chemo which so far consisted of Adriamyacin and Cytoxin (4 rounds).  I am now about to begin 4 rounds of the Taxol drugs at four and a half hour sessions every 2 weeks.  I have been told I have tolerated the first rounds of "AC" pretty well and those are usually the hardest to get through. ( I personally don't think it's been so easy ).  My doctor has said that some people who went smoothly through the AC's have a tough time with Taxol.   I have since been reading about Taxol and the pain, pre-treatment drugs and other rumors have scared me a bit.  Has anyone else out there had any experiences with taking the same drugs as me that can offer some advice for getting through the Taxol treatments. Thanks.   Andi Hi Andi, I did 4 rounds of Adriamycin with Taxol in 2002.  I had worked as a nurse for many years, taking care of many oncology patients.  I felt that my experience with the AT was not as bad as some of the problems I had seen many patients have with chemo. I lost my hair - when it started falling out I had my head shaved and wore soft caps and bandanas, reverting to no head covering once I had about 1/2 inch of hair.  I was nauseated a lot, but only ever threw up once. One of the prescription antiemetics did a good job of alleviating the nausea some, as long as I took it early and consistently. I also used concord grape juice and ginger ale (sometimes mixed) to alleviate nausea.  Bitter foods helped, also.   I always seemed to be more nauseated after I took my Neupogen - so my last round of chemo I didn't take the neupogen at all, and I actually had very little problem with nausea those last few weeks. I was very fatigued, but I also had had 3 major surgeries withing 4 months, so I expected to be fatigued.  THe worst problem I had was with the steroids - started on Prednisone - had major hallucinations, to the point that I felt very unsafe to be alone at home during the daytime.  Very disconcerting.  The next month we tried decadron - the hallucinations were about the same.  I did the last two treatments without any steroids at all - quite frankly I felt better without the steroids than I did with them.  While everybody's body chemistry is different, and it is possible the AT may affect you more harshly than the AC, it's also possible that the AT treatment won't be as bad.  Many posters to the board who have taken Taxol and are able to compare it to other chemo treatments they've had, say that the Taxol was much gentler than some of the other stuff. Also something to consider:  it's only 4 rounds.  You're already halfway there - that is practically home free when you consider all the stuff you've been through in the past year. Perhaps instead of letting yourself be overwhelmed by the idea of this change in chemo, concentrate on just getting through one day at a time - that's the best that any of us can do.  Also, concentrate on providing yourself the best physical, emotional and spiritual nourishment that you can.  Make sure to drink plenty of pure, fresh water, and eat lost of raw, fresh fruits and veggies (organic is best.) Consider taking the following combination of supplements - they are absolutely essential for anyone fighting cancer, and I cannot see that your oncologist would object to your taking them in combination with chemo. selenium:  200 mcg/day (can start with 400mcg/day but only for a few weeks) magnesium:  200 - 250 mg/day (350 mg/day max), take with food zinc:  50 mg/day (can start with 100mg/day but only for a few weeks), take with food manganese 10 - 15 mg/day, take with food calcium: 1200 mg/day We need Vitamin D-3 to be able to absorb and utilize calcium. Our bodies manufacture D-3 if we get adequate sunlight (15 - 20 minutes exposure/day) - but I do not believe in leaving this to chance, so also recommend a Vitamin D-3 supplement, 1000 - 2000 iu/day (10,000 iu/day max)  Please feel free to look at this article on my blog for ideas on other natural things you can do to  overcome this cancer and enhance your immune system:  http://motherearthtreasurechest.blogspot.com/2008/09/my-pers Let me know if you would like website references for other complementary treatments with chemo. Posts.Content: On 11/18/2008 EmmaAus wrote: Hi, my grandmother (now 84) was diagnosed with breast cancer 2 years ago and had a radical mastectomy on her left side.About 2 months ago she started complaining of pain whilst urinating and after a month of her doctor saying don't worry about it it's all in your head (i should mention at this point she also has dimentia) my mum finally took her to another doctor and after a few tests they discovered she had kidney cancer. She has been to oncologists and they recommended Chemo and Radio therapy. Now, they have discovered 2 lumps in her breasts and another cancer in her colon. I have had mixed messages from people some saying that she should still continue and start the treatments next week and other who say, it's too aggressive and with the age and dimentia as well we should just let nature take it's course. I am really after some words of wisdom from anyone who may have had to make this choice before and anyone who may know life expectancy rates in this situation. I would rather have a month or 2 of her here, with pain medication and her happy than however long it may be going through the pain of chemo (which i witnessed my mother go through when she had breast cancer 10 years ago). I am just so confused. Can anyone help? Hi EmmaAus, As a cancer survivor (endometrial cancer 2002 - cured) , a person living with cancer (breast cancer 2002, diagnosed with metastasis to lungs 2008), , and one who has lost both my best friend and my mother to cancer, if I were in your grandmother's shoes, I would say "No chemo, no radiation. Treatment using naturals  if they will help me to not have pain and to otherwise keep me as healthy as possible. Prescription drugs only for management of pain, and to keep me from having infections.  Let me enjoy the rest of my life, and when it's my time, help me to pass on with dignity." Speaking as a former RN and one who has done a lot of research on using alternatives to treat breast cancer: I'm not sure there is any major advantage to chemo/radiation at this point. Leading authorities on breast cancer are increasingly coming to believe that by the time they reach their early 80's, MOST women will have at least early breast cancer. Therefore there have already been some studies on breast cancer in the aged; most of what I've seen published indicates that for these women, there is no increase in life-span gained through chemo or radiation therapy. In fact, there is a lot of evidence that at this age, women who choose NOT to have treatment outlive those who get chemo or radiation. So in terms of "quantity" of life - maybe no advantage to treating the cancer. Thus "quality" of life becomes the main issue. With dementia, especially if it gets worse, your grandmother is already at risk for decreased quality of life.  She may have skin care problems - chemo/radiation might make that worse.  She might have nutrition problems. Chemo/radiation will DEFINITELY make those worse.  Treatment - especially if she is given steroids - is likely to interfere with her mental functioning: increasing forgetfulness, disorientation, possible "brain fog" from chemo.  As for pain, that can be treated without chemo/radiation, especially if you use natural alternatives in combination with  prescription drugs.  That leaves the question of kidney and bowel function.  Yes, eventually the metastasis is likely to cause kidney failure, but that may take a very long time. And the dementia could take her first. I would ask the dr how likely it is that she will have problems with blockages of urine and/or the bowels in comparison to how long before she might start having life-threatening problems from the dimentia, and if pain from the cancer is likely to become a major problem before the dimentia becomes life-threatening. If a short period of chemo  or radiation could significantly lessen the risk of these two factors, then perhaps I would consider going ahead with them. The other thing to consider is how bad is your grandmother's dementia.  If she is still at all capable of making decisions, I would certainly find out what she wants to do about all of this. In the end, you and your mum (and whoever else is part of the decision making process) need to go with whatever gives you the most peace in YOUR hearts, regardless of what any outsiders might say. This will enable you to continue caring for your grandmother with love and kindness, and those are the most important gifts she could receive.  Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: You could be experiencing pain from scar tissue, from poorly draining lymph nodes, from infection and/or inflammation, as well as the possibility of recurring tumor.  Get your dr to give you a thorough exam, and keep pushing for satisfactory answers.  If you don't feel you are getting a reasonable explaination and proper treatment, get a referral for a 2nd opinion.  As the consumer and the patient, you DO have the right to consult a different physician - and any dr worth his or her salt should not hesitate to provide you with a referral so that your insurance will cover it.  Also, you can ask your dr to refer you to a physical therapist well-experienced in treatment of post-mastectomy recovery.  This could include massage, physical manipulation, stretching, hydrotherapy, exercise under supervision and a home treatment plan. After a mastectomy, lymph nodes around the surgical site can get congested with crystallized drainage/secretions.  Many women report  stringy bumpy areas at about 10 months post-op - this is crystallization due to inadequate drainage.  These crystals can be broken up through gentle massage of the affected area.  Pain from post-surgical scarring can also be eased by gentle but persistent massage of the affected area.  Doesn't have to be anything fancy - doesn't even have to be prescribed by a dr or therapist.  To the extent that you can stand, gently but firmly massage the area at least several times a day - gentle pressure may at first be somewhat uncomfortable, but within a short period of time SHOULD help the area to feel better.  If gentle massage causes onset of moderate to severe pain, stop and get another exam. Unless you have another physical condition which affects your balance or mobility, You might also consider using a rebounder (mini-trampoline.)  They can be purchased fairly inexpensively, and gently bouncing for just 3 minutes twice a day can greatly improve lymph drainage, decrease lymphedema, help to break up scar tissue, improve muscle tone and circulation, plus it's a lot of fun.
