Posts.Content: Current research is suggesting that Tamoxifen is only effective for 3 - 4 years, so the 5th year might be moot, anyway. also, there is some research in the works with early results that breast cancer may be adapting to tamoxifen, as is happening with other types of cancers and other drugs.  (One might question that cancer can adapt to a drug - bacteria has adapted to antibiotics and we no longer have just MRSA, but other  types of antibiotic-resistant strains starting to appear.  Cancer is a living organism just like bacteria - it does what it must to survive, so it might not be that far of a stretch that in the future we will have at least one strain of anti-estrogen resistant breast cancer)  I don't know how long Tamoxifen will continue to be one of the big anti-estrogen guns with the development of so many new drugs, but these reports suggest that quite possibly the standard recommendation for Tamoxifen will become 3, maybe 4, years instead of 5. Perhaps this kind of research finding sounds kind of grim, but it doesn't have to.  I think one of the greatest shortcomings of the medical community in dealing with cancer is that they don't emphasize building up the immune system again once someone has successfully dealt with primary cancer.  many researchers in both the traditional treatment and alternative therapy communities alike believe that all people have at least some cancer cells in their bodies on and off throughout their lifetimes. Those who have healthy immune systems are able to fight these cancer cells off and thus do not get disease.  When something happens within an individual  to weaken the immune system, cancer cells are then able to get a foothold and start growing rapidly to produce tumors, etc, and move into the lymph, blood stream, and other tissues. So, even though you are coming off the Tamoxifen, that does not necessarily mean you should just sit back and not do anything else to assure your continued health. It makes sense that anyone who has had cancer in the past should devote continued special care to their immune system to prevent recurrence.  The easiest way to do that is through nutrition - anti-oxidants, vitamins and minerals, herbs, supplements and natural foods that act as natural cancer fighters. Exercise is also important, as is on-going detoxification with lots and lots of pure water, for both drinking and cooking. If you are already involved in a good self-care regimen that includes cancer-fighting nutrition, exercise and detoxification, chances are you're in pretty good shape for a Tamoxifen-free life - congratulations! If you AREN'T involved in these things, I recommend you start - staying cancer free needs to be a life-style rather than a prescription.  And it's an exciting life-style, because the things that help us to continue to fight any future cancer cells also help us to feel incredibly well! (My motto is "kick cancer in-the-butt, every day, all the way!") Let me know if you need help getting started in your own staying-cancer-free regimen.  I'll be glad to give you some ideas and excellent references, as I am sure other posters to this board will be also. Good luck, and congratulations on making it 4 years cancer free!!!! Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: Hi Paddy, I just saw the other message you had sent.  When someone has difficulty swallowing pills, especially with choking, I recommend trying to give them in a little bit of apple sauce or pudding or mashed potatoes before crushing them and putting them in a liquid. Masks the bitterness a little bit better, and not as much risk of inhaling the medication into the lungs. Posts.Content: On 7/3/2008 Smort9256 wrote: Can anyone advise me please? I had surgery last year and some lymph nodes were removed. I have recently started weight lifting as part of my 'fitter me' lifestyle but am worried that it might cause my arm to swell. I have not had any problems with my arm so far - but should I wear a compression sleeve 'just in case' or is this unnecessary?  If you haven't had any indication of lymphedema in general, or with other activities, you may not have a problem with exercise.  Compression sleeves are expensive, especially if you don't have insurance, so I wouldn't purchase one unless you notice your shoulder, arm, and/or hand swelling after the exercise. The other thing to watch for is undue fatigue in that arm.  That kind of muscle use generates a lot of lactic acid, which is what makes muscles feel tired.  while your lymph system in that arm may still be quite adequate to handle normal lymph circulation, you might have some problems with drainage of lactic acid from tissues.  Most people will experience only very transient muscle fatigue after sensible weight lifting.  If your arm has not recovered within 10 - 15 minutes, I would recommend you talk to your doctor, get the doctor to actually measure your arm and compare to the other arm to make sure you aren't developing lymph edema. Another indication of lymphedema is the actual feeling of fluid moving in your arm when you run your hand across it. A excellent way to help keep your arm healthy is to use a rebounder (minitrampoline.)  Bouncing on a rebounder twice a day for 3 minutes each time is an excellent way to promote lymph drainage back to the chest.  You don't have to do anything fancy, just bounce gently.  I got my rebounder at a discount department store - you don't have to get the real fancy models - just a basic 36" inch minitrampoline is all you need.  make sure to bounce AFTER your weight-lifting sessions. One thing to avoid:  steam rooms or saunas.  A lot of ladies like to use the heat to loosen muscles before exercise, and for relaxation after exercise.  But that kind of heat can cause problems for women who have had lymph nodes removed - actually causes increased congestion in the arm instead of improving circulation. And it's always a good idea to go slowly and gently with exercise when there is a question. Take care, Tre

Posts.Content: I forgot one thing:  You might want to consider doing MLD - manual lymph drainage (self-massage) of that arm after exercise and before rebounding.  You can probably find instructions online, or else ask your dr to give you a one-time referral to whomever in your area is skilled in MLD and can teach you how to do it.  (I learned at the rehab place where I got my compression sleeve, I don't know if insurance will cover such a visit without an official diagnosis of lymphedema, but if you can afford it, it certainly would be well-worth the cost to learn from a professional.) Posts.Content: Hi Bluefootedbooby, Lumpectomy does not guarantee for anybody that the surgeon will get all the cancer, but truthfully, neither does mastectomy.   That's why they do the radiation - to catch any seeds of cancer that have broken away from the primary site into the surrounding tissues or the lymph system. While with mastectomy you might be able to avoid radiation, there are considerations other than that and reconstruction.  With mastectomy they remove a lot more tissue, and that means a lot more damage to the lymph system with the possibility of resultant problems.  Also a lot more initial challenge to the body - longer time under anesthesia, a greater chance of infection, and more demands on the body for greater tissue healing.  With lumpectomy they try not only to save breast tissue, but to keep as much of the lymph system intact as possible - the lymph system is the major cleansing network for the body - our chests need that protection. With mastectomy, that protection will be removed.  Surgeons take all that into account when they recommend breast-conservation (lumpectomy) and radiation, but I think patients have a right to be informed of those risks as well. I had a large tumor located very high in the tail of my left breast (almost totally up under the arm.  I had a lumpectomy - left quite a large divot on the outside border of my breast, but I am fortunate in that I did not need reconstruction.  We already knew I had some lymph node involvement going into surgery; unfortunately, there were cancer cells in the margins of the tissue the surgeon took out, so I had to have another surgery and have more lymph nodes removed.  After both surgeries, I made an effort to take good care of my arm, and had no signs of lymph edema going into radiation several months later. With radiation, I began to get lymphedema  - more lymph nodes were being damaged by the radiation and I just didn't have enough left to provide adequate drainage.  I chose to stop the radiation about half-way through, preferring to take my chances that the cancer might recur rather than moving forward with the pretty definite knowledge that the few remaining functioning lymph nodes I had left might also be irreversibly damaged and that I might have to live with a constant severe lymphedema.  (My livelihood depended upon use of my hands and arms - for me the choice was one of quality of life rather than quantity.) So obviously  lumpectomy is not a guaranteed easier ride for everyone, but at the outset, surgically it does present fewer risks.  And there always is the option of having more breast tissue removed in future.  However, radiation presents immediate risks other than just burning of the skin, and radiation makes future surgery possibly not go as well - that's a consideration, also. In late 2007 we found nodules in my lungs, in Feb 2008 I had a surgical biopsy with definite diagnosis of metastatic breast cancer. 6 1/2 years after my breast surgeries, I am now a survivor in remission due to alternative treatment, and planning to stay that way!  My future is not guaranteed ( no one's is!), but if I had to choose again with the possibility of a different outcome, I believe I would make the exact same choices, because they were the choices that brought me the most peace then, and I am at peace with them now. Quite possibly you have a "gut feeling" about what you want to do, but are trying to make the most logical and well-informed choice.  But listen to your gut feeling, too; seriously take into consideration the way you "feel" about your choices -  sometimes our inner being has some pretty good wisdom of its own.  I wish you well with however you decide to go.  Please keep us informed of your progress.  We will offer you support, and do the happy dance with you as you get through each step! Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: Hi Lollypop. In the past I have always advised going straight to biopsy to make certain - and actually went that route myself. But in more recent days as I've continued to research diagnosis and treatment, I've come to question that "wisdom." Certainly, biopsy is the only  "sure" way to know if cells are cancer (and even then it's not fool-proof), but biopsy in itself may present a risk that scientists and drs have been loath to consider:  specifically the possibility of taking a well-contained cancer and seeding it to other tissues. So, maybe consider taking the middle ground.  If you have the insurance coverage, get the MRI done first. That will show you if there is a really compelling reason for biopsy  - if not, then you've saved yourself some pain. If biopsy is  indicated from the MRI, you would only have a matter of several weeks delay at the most. Go with your gut feelings - do what you need to do to take prudent action while at the same time trying to minimize risk. Sincerely, Tre

My 51 sister has battled  breast cancer since 03.  In 05 it became metastasized in bones and brain.   Onto yesterday,  her Dr. put her on 2 ml of morphine every 1-2 hrs anf 2 xanax (.25 mg) every 2 hrs.  All of this has been prn.  Kelly ( my sis) is aware that this will take care of the pain, also it will make her sleep.  My "other" 3 sisters are aware of it also.  We are forunate to have Hospice. Our nurse will be here tomorrow.  They are on call on the weekends.  That is how we were able to start the morphine.  We were told last Tuesday that it could be anytime... are we closer than we think.  Kelly has stated that she is probably more ready for this than we are. With everything I have told you, do you have any advice?  I noticed the other night that you had been a RN. God bless for the work that you did and the work that you're doing. Hi Paddy, I don't remember if I sent you this link or not - you may have seen it from where I posted it for someone else.  If not, please take a look at it.  Sounds like much of what is in the link you already know, but sometimes it helps just to see things in writing. http://www.virtualtrials.com/btlinks/death.cfm If Kelly was just started on the liquid morphine, she probably isn't on too high a dosage, yet. So she might not have respiratory suppression, but I still imagine the morphine is going to make her very sleepy.  Which is probably a good thing, if she is hurting. As for how long she has, that's really difficult to say, especially since I'm not there to assess her condition myself.   She's been fighting mets to the bone and brain for what? 3 - 4 years? And that's just since it was diagnosed - possible that the metastasis had been there quite a while before you all found out about it. So I guess the real determinants at this stage are overall health - if Kelly's nutrition has been good, if she doesn't have any overlying problems - heart condition, kidney or liver problems,etc - if may be a matter of whether or not the metastasis in the brain is bad enough that it shuts down her heart and lungs. If not, then it might be a matter of how well she tolerates the morphine, xanax, etc. Many people that are dependant upon the high-powered narcotics succumb to the respiratory depression caused by the drugs before they succumb to the physical cancer.  Pneumonia can become a serious concern when someone is highly immobile, as can the possibility of just building up fluid in the lungs from the immobility. And it's really hard to say how long that might take, or if it will happen at all. If Kelly is at peace with this process, has given herself permission to go, and feels that she has permission from the family to go, she may go fairly quickly - but that isn't always the case.  I think the best thing to do in a situation like this is to count everyday that you have with her as a blessing. Tell Kelly you love her.  Talk with her - about anything or everything, or just nothing.  It's not the content of talking that matters, but rather the companionship.  Or encourage people to just sit with her while she sleeps.  It can be a tremendous comfort to her - even though she may be asleep, she most likely at some level will be aware that someone is there with her, and it really helps when that someone is a close loved one. Of course family can't sit with her 100% of the time, and that's what Hospice is for.  This is hard - I'm sure Kelly would like to have an end to this pain.  Just reassure her that when her body says it's time to go, then it's ok to go.  We can't know why a body doesn't quit when the mind and spirit have agreed that it's ok to go.  My grandmother will be 100 years old in one month.  She's fought Parkinson's disease for many years.  She lived by herself with aides coming in to help her with bathing and cooking up until about 2 months ago when she had a mini-stroke.  She's in a nursing home now - she doesn't like having lost her independence.  Her sister, who was her best friend, has just recently passed away.  My grandmother says that she thinks she could pass at any time now, and she is ok with that, yet her stubborn old body just keeps working!  We don't know why that is - we just know that is IS, and that's what we have to work with.  When the time is right, she will move on. It's not the same situation physically with your sister, but I think it's really the same metaphysical question:  we don't know how long it will take, or why it takes so long when they are ready to go. I wish I had a better answer for you, but all I can say is that yes, in terms of comparison to how long your sister has been fighting this cancer from first diagnosis, yes, the end is very near.  IN the matter of hours or days or weeks, I would guess that it might be a week at least, or perhaps several weeks or even longer, unless something very specific happens first to weaken her further.  And I could be very wrong .... Hang in there - this is not easy, but there will come a day that you know your sister has found release from her pain and struggle, and while that will be heart-breaking, it will also be comforting. Try to take good care of yourself, and encourage your "other" sisters to do the same. Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: Hi Nancy, Thanks for the update.  I'm sorry you had to go back for more surgery.  There were cells in the margins when I had my lumpectomy, so I had to go back for revision and lymph dissection.  That 2nd go-round certainly isn't fun. I hope your radiation goes well.  Remember to stay well hydrated - even though they're not pumping a lot of chemicals into you, you still will be having cellular death - lots of debris floating around in your bloodstream, etc - so detoxification is very important, and that can't happen if you're dehydrated.  Also, try to really consume as many anti-oxidant and vitamin B - rich foods as your dr says is ok - especially the cruciferous veggies and fruits such as citrus and berries. Sincerely, Tre
